Antitrust: The European Union has once again kicked a giant U.S. tech firm in the shins in yet another pathetic fit of jealous pique. Last time, it was Apple (AAPL), supposedly because it didn't pay enough taxes. This time, it's Google, largely because, well, European companies just can't compete.XThe EU's so-called Competition Commission — whose name suggests the same level of irony as the Ministry of Truth did in George Orwell's "1984" — says that Alphabet (GOOGL) subsidiary Google must cough up a record fine of $2.7 billion because Europe's homegrown firms can't compete."Google abused its market dominance as a search engine by promoting its own comparison shopping service in its search results, and demoting those of competitors," said the EU's top antitrust bureaucrat, Margrethe Vestager. "What Google has done is illegal under EU rules."This is a really unique idea. A company comes up with a great, new, innovative service that it does better than anyone else. It then takes advantage of that service's uniquely inventive characteristics to help its own business grow and to benefit all its customers — something the world's most successful businesses do all the time.And yet, the EU defines that as "anti-competitive"?This is nothing less than an attack on American innovation and inventiveness by a jealous foreign bureaucracy. And it's a problem that's not limited to just the U.S."Recently, questionable antitrust probes have grown like topsy around the world, many of them aimed at America's most creative high-tech firms," wrote Alden Abbott, deputy director of the Edwin Meese III Center for Legal and Judicial Studies at The Heritage Foundation. "Beneficial innovations have become legal nightmares — good for defense lawyers, but bad for free market competition and the health of the American economy."The fact is, Europeans use Google's search service not because there are no other choices, but because they like it. It has lots of functions. When they stop liking it, they'll use another search engine. Google, to its credit, has added more and more functions over the years, making it extraordinarily useful — basic searches, maps, satellite images, roadside pictures of virtually every road, highway and street in every major city on Earth, entire libraries online, the list goes on and on.Yet, the linchpin of the EU "case" against Google, if it can be called that, is that Google gave pride of place to its own shopping service when displaying search results.True enough. But as Abbott notes, "This is akin to saying that Kroger (KR) or Wal-Mart (WMT) harm competition when they give favorable shelf space displays to their house brands. That's ridiculous."He's right. If anything, the EU's attack on Google — and on Amazon.com (AMZN), Apple and Microsoft (MSFT) before them — is a transparent attack on the U.S.' world-leading tech industry, which the EU can't match, and our prosperity. Instead of reforming its own socialistic and outdated industrial policies, it instead hobbles its competitors with unwarranted and possibly illegal intrusions on companies' rights to their own patents and to run their own businesses as they see fit. That European companies can't compete is their own problem.Sure, Google isn't too worried about the fine. Though huge at $2.7 billion, Google has $92 billion in cash in the bank, and won't go bankrupt from the EU's action. But, as we said, this is worrisome not just for Google, but for all U.S. tech firms, which now face spurious antitrust legal actions around the world to keep them from dominating global markets.In a piece this week in IBD, former Justice Department Deputy Assistant Attorney General for Antitrust James F. Rill argues "the potential misuse of competition law to further industrial policy is now a key area of focus for lawmakers, regulators and private enterprises."And it should be. Nor should citizens of the EU be happy with these policies. They'll face fewer choices, not more, higher prices, and less innovation in their markets, thanks to the meddling of the European Union's antitrust warriors.Besides, there's a reason why companies in the increasingly socialistic and bureaucratic EU struggle to compete on an equal footing in the global tech world: They're smothered by their own EU bureaucracy, which prescribes in excruciating and mind-numbing detail all that European businesses must do. This includes everything from workhours and labor conditions to what ingredients their products have and even what they call their products.In short, in the name of  "competition," Vestager and others of her Eurocratic ilk have helped turn the 28-nation EU into a stagnant economy where innovation is viewed as a threat, since its own companies lag the U.S., Japan and China in innovation, patents and startups.It's one thing if the EU wants to destroy its own once-thriving culture of entrepreneurship and innovation, quite another if it wants to abuse the idea of antitrust enforcement to hobble the U.S.' best companies.Both the president and Congress should work together to put an end to this kind of abusive antitrust behavior by foreign governments. It's time to put a halt to these peevish, anti-free market assaults on American innovation.RELATED:Apple Now, Google, Amazon Next? Why EU Hates Successful U.S. FirmsThe Real Lesson From Apple CEO Tim Cook's Fight With The EUCelebrating Euro-Sclerosis

Amazon.com (AMZN), Facebook (FB) and Broadcom (AVGO) are three stocks that show why $1.7 billion USAA Growth & Income Fund (USGRX) is smart for using two oars rather than just one.The fund's management is divvied up between two teams, one tilting toward value-oriented stock, the other toward growth stocks. Last year, when the postelection Trump Bump lifted value-oriented stocks like energy and financials, bets in those sectors boosted the fund's value-oriented sleeve. This year it's the growth sleeve's turn to shine brighter.And with year-to-date gains of 34% for both Amazon and Facebook and 39% for Broadcom going into Thursday, those stocks have added octane to the growth sleeve's fuel. So have consumer discretionary names like Royal Caribbean (RCL) and Norwegian Cruise Lines (NCLH). And likewise for health care names like Hologic (HOLX) and UnitedHealth Group (UNH).The fund aims for a 60%-40% split in assets between its growth and value sleeves. "That split makes sense in achieving a core fund experience for our shareholders," said USAA's Wasif Latif, who oversees the teams running the two sleeves. Subadvisors from Barrow, Hanley, Mewhinney & Strauss run the value sleeve. An in-house team from USAA mans the growth sleeve.Most of the fund's dividend comes from the Barrow Hanley sleeve.The tandem arrangement has resulted in a 23.46% return over the 12 months going into Thursday, topping 95% of its large-cap-blend rivals tracked by Morningstar Inc. The S&P 500 was up 19.06%.So far this year, the fund is up 9.74% vs. 8.82% for its peer group and 9.86% for the big-cap bogey.John Jares, who runs the growth sleeve along with John Toohey, likes Amazon's strength in retail and web services. "It's referred to as Hurricane Amazon because it's so disruptive," he said. Amazon Web Services' operating margin soared to 24.3% as of the first quarter, up from 3.8% in 2014. It's expected to hit 29% by the end of 2017, he says. With AWS' profit growing much faster than the overall company's, the overall company's operating margin will be pulled up by AWS, Jares adds. And its rapidly growing free cash flow will give the company "more ammunition to invest against any of its competitors," he said.He's less enthused about Amazon's takeover of Whole Foods Market (WFM), wondering what role it will play in Amazon's future.His team is crunching numbers to decide whether investors have oversold other grocery chains. The fund also owns Kroger (KR).Jares likes the way Facebook has become a magnet for advertising dollars, largely by providing advertisers with sharper targeting of consumers. "They can see the effectiveness of ad campaigns," Jares said. And Facebook can post additional ads at minimal cost. "That's what attracted us to the stock," he said.The stock is trading around 153. Jares says 200 is not out of the range of possibility.A third cruise ship line that the fund owns is Carnival (CCL). "The cruise lines have been on a tear this year," he said, referring to all three of his cruise ship stocks. "Because of improved demand, they've had better pricing. Last year, there were problems from terrorism in Europe, fears about the Zika virus. With the improvement in employment and the future economic outlook of the U.S., cruise lines have seen rising demand. Plus, they've enjoyed easy comps (earnings comparisons) from last year."Royal Caribbean is up 39% so far this year. Earnings per share grew 13%, 31% and 74% the past three quarters.IBD'S TAKE: Royal Caribbean ranks No. 3 in the Leisure-Services industry group. It has four straight years of annual earnings per share growth. Norwegian ranks No. 6 in the group. You can compare the two stocks fundamental and technical strengths in IBD's easy to use Stock Checkup tool.Norwegian, trading around 55, is up 29% this year. The stock is within its buy range for investors looking for optimal entry points.In health care, Jares says his team likes Hologic because relatively new CEO Stephen MacMillan is shifting the company to a faster growth profile serving female health, diagnostics and aesthetics.The team's view of UnitedHealth is that investors have underappreciated its Optum division, which includes a number of fast-growing ancillary businesses that improve the effectiveness of their standard insurance business.Building materials maker Owens Corning (OC), in the Barrow Hanley sleeve, is up 30% this year. EPS grew 9% and 60% the past two quarters. The stock has been driven by the housing rebound and strength in the U.S. economy.Michael Nayfa, a manager of the Barrow Hanley sleeve, said, "Underlying fundamentals remain strong in the roofing and composite businesses, and the insulation business looks set to recover in 2017 as housing starts remain below normal and pricing is picking up. OC remains an attractive value trading at 14 times normalized earnings with a 1.2% dividend yield."RELATED: Microsoft would surpass Amazon Web ServicesUSAA Growth & Income Fund Shows Two Heads Are Better Than OneHow To Turn A Glass Of Wine Into A $173,000 Bump In Your IRA

Supermarket chain Kroger (KR) is expected to maintain its streak of double-digit earnings growth when it reports third-quarter results this week, though gains on the top and bottom lines are likely to decelerate from the previous quarter. Meanwhile, the Cincinnati-based company is also expected to finalize its $800 million acquisition of supermarket chain Roundy's (RNDY) in the next few weeks.…

Kroger stock jumped to a record high Thursday after the supermarket chain beat quarterly earnings views on strong same-store sales growth and lower costs.The Cincinnati-based grocery giant reported adjusted earnings of 43 cents a share for its fiscal third quarter, which ended in October. That was up 23% from the prior year and 4 cents ahead of consensus. It was the 14th straight quarter of double-digit earnings growth.Kroger (KR) revenue gained 0.4% to $25.1 billion, in line with estimates. Top-line growth has been sluggish in recent quarters, partly because of lower fuel prices.However, its identical supermarket sales have been growing at a pretty rapid clip, helped by a bigger emphasis on fast-growing organic and natural foods.Q3 identical supermarket sales excluding fuel rose 5.4% vs. a year earlier — above consensus for a 4.5% increase. That followed Q2's 5.3% core comps gain.Meanwhile, expenses fell as a share of total sales on cost curbs.Kroger stock rose 4.7% to 39.91, breaking out to a record high.Kroger has managed to beat expectations despite several headwinds, RBC Capital Markets analyst William Kirk said in a Thursday note.These headwinds include rising competition from Wal-Mart (WMT) as well as Winter Haven, Fla.-based Publix, a privately held chain that mainly operates in the Southeast."Kroger continues to be one of the best operators in the category, but will be less immune to deflationary pressures than it has been year-to-date," Kirk noted.One thing Kroger has done well lately is grab market share in organic and natural foods from more focused rivals such as Whole Foods Market (WFM) and Fresh Market (TFM).Kroger entered the organic foods business with its Simple Truth brand and recently said that natural and organic foods accounted for 10% of total sales."Simple Truth continues to grow at an astonishing rate, set ting a record high for total sales in the third quarter while continuing to establish weekly sales records throughout the quarter," CFO Michael Schlotman said on a conference call with analysts.Kroger raised its full-year EPS guidance to $2.02-$2.04 from $1.92-$1.98. Analysts expected $2 EPS before the Q3 earnings beat.Meanwhile, Kroger is expected to finalize its $800 million acquisition of Roundy's (RNDY) in the next few weeks, in a deal that will expand its presence in the Midwest.Whole Foods stock fell 0.1%; Fresh Market lost 0.7%.

When it comes to holiday wish lists, gift cards remain a top choice among consumers this season. That's music to the ears of prepaid card and payments company Blackhawk Network (HAWK)."Blackhawk is one of the big providers of gift cards and related services," Wedbush Securities analyst Gil Luria told Investor's Business Daily. "It helps content providers like retailers that want to sell outside their premises on grocery store shelves."Blackhawk uses proprietary technology to offer a broad range of prepaid gift, telecom and debit cards, in physical and electronic forms, as well as related prepaid products and payment services. The company supports the management and distribution of these products in a number of different retail, digital and incentive channels.It sells to consumers through its retail distribution network, whether in stores or on websites. Blackhawk also provides services, software and prepaid products to business clients for loyalty, incentive and reward programs, using its own sales force, as well as third-party resellers.23 CountriesBlackhawk's retail distribution partners showcase gift cards on displays that Blackhawk manages. Outside the U.S., Blackhawk distributes to its non-U.S. partners in 23 countries via grocery stores and other retail channels.The company seems to be in the right place at the right time. Gift cards remained the most requested holiday gift by consumers in a November National Retail Federation survey. And a recent poll by Deloitte found redeemable cards are the No. 2 gift that shoppers plan to buy this holiday.Consumers showed just how popular gift cards are over the Thanksgiving/Black Friday weekend. Stored Value Solutions reports sales of gift cards in the U.S. were up 4% year over year for the four days of the Thanksgiving holiday weekend, double 2014's year-over-year gain of 2%.Blackhawk distributes merchant-branded prepaid, or "closed-loop," cards for companies such as Amazon (AMZN), Apple's (AAPL) iTunes, Macy's (M), Starbucks (SBUX)and Best Buy (BBY), in addition to other prepaid products like telecom cards, open-loop gift cards that can be redeemed anywhere, and reloadable prepaid debit cards.The company isn't content with that, however. Blackhawk has bulked up with a steady flow of acquisitions, new businesses and expanded distribution. That's helped it gain traction in its traditional space and in the "incentive" gift card arena, where customers are rewarded for loyalty.New DivisionMany of the buyouts are part of a new division, Blackhawk Engagement Solutions, that was formed this year."Our strategy since inception has been to connect great brands to consumers through a productive global network," Teri Llach, Blackhawk's chief marketing officer, told IBD. "Motivating employees via a prepaid card or gift card is a logical expansion going from a retail presence, where we're connecting brands to consumers, to corporate incentives, where we're connecting employers to employees."The incentives and rewards business has proven to be the fastest-growing segment for Blackhawk and is driving its rapid expansion, says Wedbush's Luria."Their biggest business, which is closed-loop gift cards, has slowed down to maybe single-digit growth," Luria said. "To generate growth, they've been making acquisitions of these corporate incentives and rewards companies."Showing In NumbersIt's showing up in the numbers. In the third quarter, Blackhawk's adjusted earnings grew 52% to 35 cents a share. Adjusted revenue jumped 54% to $193.4 million.Its incentives and rewards segment's adjusted operating revenues soared 392% from a year earlier, primarily due to the acquisition of Parago and the purchase of Achievers, Chief Executive Bill Tauscher said in a recent press release. Meanwhile, its U.S. retail segment grew adjusted operating revenue 21% in the third quarter. The international retail segment posted adjusted operating revenue growth of 27%.Luria says the corporate incentives and rewards business is more of a year-round concern, while the company's core gift card segment is seasonal, with all of its business generated in the fourth quarter around the holidays. Luria expects the company to continue to make acquisitions since its core business is slowing down.Latest PurchaseBlackhawk's latest buy came last month with the purchase of Didix Gifting & Promotions.Based in the Netherlands, Didix issues and markets leisure-themed gifts and promotions using a prepaid card that can be redeemed for services at multiple leisure outlets, including regional retailers, restaurants, cinemas and spas. It develops gifting and promotional products and brands across the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, Germany and Belgium.Blackhawk's Llach says all of the company's acquisitions have been a "significant driver of Blackhawk's earnings growth.""We are in 23 countries, and we are looking at smart ways to expand where we see a market (opportunity)," Llach said.Safeway SpinoffBlackhawk was spun off from privately held grocery giant Safeway in 2014. Safeway and other grocers such as Kroger (KR) are distribution partners.Other partners include Home Depot (HD), Lowe's (LOW) and Staples (SPLS) as well as online giants Amazon and eBay (EBAY).Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Blackhawk's full-year 2015 earnings to rise 31% to $2.31 a share. They see a 14% gain in 2016 and an 11% increase in 2017."As long as they continue to make acquisitions, they will grow (at a rapid) rate," said Luria. "At some point it will be harder to do. If they run out of balance-sheet ability (because of too much debt), it will be harder for them to borrow more money to make acquisitions."Blackhawk is part of IBD's Finance-Credit Card/Payment Processors industry group. It leads the group with a 99 IBD Composite Rating out of a possible 99.

The broadest, timeliest data on the health of the job market show that financial markets may be wrong about the economy.Federal employment and income taxes withheld from paychecks rose a strong 6.2% from a year ago over the past 10 weeks, an IBD analysis of daily Treasury statements shows. That growth reflects, in part, wage increases at companies like American Airlines (AAL) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Jack in the Box (JACK).By comparison, tax withholdings grew a modest 4.3% during the same period in 2016.The latest 10-week period of data provides a clearer signal on pay, as it started in early April. The year-over-year growth rate spiked early this year during bonus season, which wrapped up at the end of March.After accounting for roughly 2% payroll growth, the 6% gain in tax withholdings implies paychecks are about 4% larger than a year ago, reflecting higher wages as well as more hours and incentive pay.That presents a much different picture than Labor Department numbers showing that average hourly wage growth fell back to 2.5% in May. It also contrasts with the view held by markets, which see falling inflation and tepid wage growth.While the Federal Reserve's hawkish outlook calls for four more rate hikes over the next 18 months, markets are pricing in just one quarter-point hike through June 2018.The picture offered by the tax data seems roughly consistent with what companies have been saying in their earnings calls.Companies like Jack in the Box, AutoZone (AZO) and Union Pacific (UNP) have reported accelerating wage pressures in recent months, while American Airlines and JPMorgan Chase implemented broad pay hikes. Last week, Kroger (KR) said it moved to "increase starting wages to try to reduce the turnover we have," even as it faces a price war against Wal-Mart (WMT).On a June 6 conference call, Casey's General Stores (CASY) CFO Bill Walljasper talked about a "very tight" labor market in which "it's not uncommon for people to jump shifts, $0.25 raise here or there, and so that's been a challenge," according to a Seeking Alpha transcript."We've definitely seen that throughout our market and some of these wage rate pressures for us to remain competitive around some of the noncore hours of the 24 hours stores, the pizza delivery, things of that nature," Walljasper said.IBD'S TAKE: Wall Street is increasingly of the view that the Federal Reserve has an ulterior motive for its hawkish policy tilt in the face of falling inflation: reining in the stock market. If so, the Fed has so far been impotent. On Monday, IBD upgraded its market outlook to a confirmed uptrend as the Nasdaq enjoyed its best day of 2017.Jack in the Box says it's seeing 6% wage inflation, driven in part by minimum-wage increases. AutoZone CEO Bill Rhodes noted "accelerated pressures on wages," with minimum-wage increases playing a secondary role. "Probably the larger portion is being driven by general market pressures with lower unemployment and some specific actions taken in recent years by other retailers," Rhodes said on a May 22 call.Those "other retailers" likely include Wal-Mart, which raised its base wage to $10 an hour in early 2016.RELATED:Fed Hikes Rates, But Hawkish Tone Unnerves MarketsSlow Hiring, 16-Year Low Jobless Rate Shift Fed Outlook

XWhole Foods Market (WFM) shares continued to climb Monday, signaling increased belief that someone else could top the $13.7 billion Amazon.com (AMZN) deal for the high-end grocer.Barclays analyst Karen Short said she "would not be surprised if there is a bidding war" for Whole Foods, upgrading the high-end grocer to overweight from equal weight and raising her price target by 26% to 48, well above Amazon's announced acquisition price of 42 a share.A fresh bid could be as high as 57 a share, Short says, giving a big potential upside. Meanwhile, the regulatory risk for Amazon's deal is low, so the potential downside from buying Whole Foods shares is low in her view. And beyond fending off the e-commerce giant, Short added that a strategic retail bidder could create up to $600 million in synergies.Is this a plausible scenario? Barclays isn't the only one that seems to think so. Oppenheimer upped its price target to 45 on Friday, not long after the deal was announced, on the grounds that the deal undervalued Whole Foods' prospects and "powerful brand." Analysts there see a mid-40s-range buyout as more appropriate.Shares of Whole Foods Market rose 1.3% to 43.22 in the stock market today — even after closing up 29.1% on Friday to 42.68.So who, exactly, could pop out of the woodwork to beat Amazon's $13.7 billion offer? In Short's view, the list of suspects is long: "all retailers that sell food and compete with (Amazon) because we think most have too much to lose not to bid." Kroger (KR), Target (TGT) and Wal-Mart (WMT) are on that list.The nation's grocery chains and big-box stores have already lost a lot since Friday, as shares of Kroger, Target, Wal-Mart and Costco (COST) suffered mightily from the merger announcement.(The only grocery retailer that isn't getting further kicked Monday on news of the deal is Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) — and that's likely because Oppenheimer pegged it as the next possible takeover target. Sprouts rose 3.5% on Monday.)Kroger rose 1.6%, but after crashing nearly 28% last week. Wal-Mart edged up 0.3% while Target fell 1.7%.Costco continues to suffer Monday, falling 2.7% to a 2017 low and undercutting its 200-day moving average. Deutsche Bank downgraded Costco to hold, citing intensifying competition from efforts by Amazon and Wal-Mart to ramp up their in-store and online business.The Whole Foods acquisition "represents a game changer with (Costco's) competitive moat of grocery under greater threat while its digital platform lags peers, putting membership renewal at higher risk for decline," wrote Deutsche's Paul Trussell. He cut his price target on Costco to 172 from 187.Still, the membership warehouse's traffic and margins are solid, he said. And Cowen's Oliver Chen, who has an outperform rating on Costco, believes the retailer's vertical integration and low prices will continue to be brick-and-mortar traffic drivers.For his part, Chen isn't so sure that Costco would be interested in — or Target would be capable of — proposing a buyout for Whole Foods, and Wal-Mart might only have interest insomuch as a buyout would be a defensive measure. But he is wondering about Amazon's next shopping spree."We believe there are likely capabilities, routes to market, and specialized brand propositions at retailers which could be synergistically combined with largely pure-play online retailers such as (Amazon)," wrote Chen.Who? Why, Nordstrom (JWN), Urban Outfitters (URBN), Ascena Retail Group (ASNA) or even RH (RH) (formerly known as Restoration Hardware).Those might be some pretty unexpected names for a potential Amazon takeover — but then again, so was Whole Foods.RELATED:Are These Amazon's Next Five Targets?What Amazon's Whole Foods Deal Means For RetailAmazon-Whole Foods Merger Could Be 'Category Killer' For Food, Eateries

Amazon.com (AMZN) — the Nasdaq's fourth-largest-weighted stock — jumped more than 2% on the acquisition of Whole Foods Market (WFM).The S&P 500 erased early losses all the way into the close and finished a fraction higher. After last Friday's sell-off, the market didn't do enough to recover and remains under pressure.The Dow Jones industrial average added 0.1%. Wal-Mart (WMT), which could be hurt by the Amazon-Whole Foods deal, skidded nearly 5% in about six times more volume than usual. Wal-Mart closed below the 50-day moving average for the first time since Feb. 15.Small caps performed in line with the Nasdaq as the Russell 2000 slipped 0.2%. Since it hit a new high June 9, it's fallen four of the next five days. The Dow utilities outperformed with a 0.4% increase to a record high.Volume was sharply higher amid the simultaneous expiration of various options and futures contracts. Despite that, indexes closed mostly lower. Winning stocks led losers by nearly 6-to-5 on the NYSE. But on the Nasdaq, losers topped winners by 8-to-7.Besides Amazon's internet retail industry group, energy, fiber optics and some health care groups were among the best performing. Finisar's (FNSR) 8% surge after strong quarterly results was the main cause of the fiber-optic industry's rise Friday.The retail sector was broadly lower, with discount chains, drugstores and office supply retailers down 2% to 5%. The grocery stores group was only modestly lower. Whole Foods' 29% surge cushioned sharp losses in Kroger (KR), Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) and several smaller stocks in the same group.Kroger already had tumbled 19% Thursday on an earning warning, and lost 9% more Friday. The week's 27% plunge left shares at their lowest level in more than three years.RELATED:What Amazon's Whole Foods Deal Means For RetailAmazon-Whole Foods Deal Lifts Impinj Stock; IDT Gets Price-Target HikeKroger Trashed, Rival Grocers Spoiled On Earnings Warning

X Unhinge jaw, devour Whole Foods Market (WFM). Amazon's (AMZN) latest acquisition is its largest ever at $13.7 billion, and one that promises to shake up the retail space — though exactly how is unclear.A combined Amazon and Whole Foods Market would create the fifth largest U.S. grocery retailer behind Wal-Mart (WMT), Kroger (KR), Costco (COST) and Albertsons/Safeway, said Cowen analyst John Blackledge in a Friday note.As Investor's Business Daily has previously reported, Amazon's foray into the grocery aisle isn't new. Through Amazon Fresh and Prime Pantry, Amazon already has some level of grocery-delivery built into its fulfillment strategy, though the complexity of handling produce and perishables at its fulfillment centers means that the rollout has been relatively slow.It was not until the latter half of 2016 that Amazon "meaningfully ramped up its expansion efforts" to be in approximately 20 major U.S. markets, wrote Blackledge in an earlier report from March.Engulfing Whole Foods now brings 460 additional brick-and-mortar locations in the U.S., Canada and the U.K., and around 87,000 more employees to Amazon's arsenal. Whole Foods raked in $16 billion in sales in fiscal 2016.That expanded presence in the real world could mean all manner of retail ripples. Amazon could use the acquisition to increase its product offering through Prime Now or expand its beta-tested curbside pickup offering, among other things, noted Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson. The e-commerce titan could also incorporate its private-label items, "compressing costs and removing differentiation currently enjoyed by retailers like (Wal-Mart)."Whole Foods will expand Amazon Fresh's potential footprint to most of the U.S., especially in upscale areas, Olson added. "We believe Amazon can therefore launch nationwide grocery delivery coverage within 12-18 months."For Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM), "it will likely complicate its delivery partnership with AMZN through Amazon Prime Now," wrote UBS analyst Michael Lasser. Amazon and Sprouts announced a Denver grocery delivery partnership on Thursday.Additionally, "we consider it to be a negative read for (Target), as it could further complicate its efforts to gain traction creating a stronger, better-for-you food offering in its stores," he said.The buyout could also increase the existing allure of Amazon's Prime membership.In the cybersphere, Amazon Prime was already the "most used" platform to buy groceries online in 2016, according to a Cowen survey from March. Prime's 47% share outguns Wal-Mart 39% piece of the pie, and Cowen's Blackledge added that the U.S. grocery retail market is "greatly underpenetrated online," projecting earlier this year that online grocery sales could reach $177 billion in 2022, up from an estimated $71 billion this year.And there appears to be plenty of room to grow within Amazon's own ecosystem: Consulting firm Magid said only 13% of Prime subscribers buy groceries on Amazon.Analyst reaction has been swift. BMO Capital Markets upped its price target on Whole Foods to 42, Amazon's offer price. Oppenheimer raised its target on Whole Foods to 45 from 40, and said it can't rule out the possibility of another bid for the upscale grocer as a defense measure against Amazon.Some investors apparently agree with Oppenheimer. Whole Foods shares shot up 29.1% to 42.68 on the stock market today. Amazon rose 2.4% to 987.71.Calling the buyout a "somewhat surprising step" from Amazon, RBC analyst Mark Mahaney also noted surprise that Amazon is wading further into brick-and-mortar retail.The question of what Whole Foods can bring to Amazon appears to be answerable in a dozen different ways. A murkier question appears to be what Amazon can do for Whole Foods."We could see AMZN perhaps improving WFM's procurement processes, but it's very unclear to us how Amazon would improve the rest of WFM's operations," said Mahaney, noting that Amazon "has typically not bought fixer-uppers.""So we see substantial execution risk here, offset only by the reality that in the AMZN scheme of things, this is actually a relatively modest acquisition," he wrote.UBS' Lasser sees potential for "deeper price investments" at Whole Foods, which he says is "necessary" to re-accelerate same-store sales growth at the grocer.Looking to Amazon's peer in China might offer some clues about what comes next in the plan."If you look at Alibaba (BABA) and what they've been able to do in China with the grocery stores that they've invested in, that might be a model, but you don't know because Amazon is always going to be on the forefront," ACSI Funds CEO Phil Bak told Investor's Business Daily. Amazon and Whole Foods Market are both holdings in the company's fund.Alibaba recently inked a deal with Chinese supermarket heavyweight Shanghai Bailian Group, which has 4,700 locations in the country, and the China e-commerce giant has an approximate one-third stake in Sanjiang Shopping Club.Amazon "is not following anyone else's model," said Bak. "They're going to pave the way, and they're going to create a new model for how grocery shopping can be."One thing is clear: This massive acquisition means that the list of Amazon-proof stores is getting smaller."As other brick and mortar retailers have come to realize the hard way that competing with Amazon is a formidable challenge, supermarkets will now have to contend with not only competition with each other and nontraditional grocers like Wal-Mart and Target, but with a retailer like Amazon which has the financial capacity to price aggressively," said Moody's Vice President Mickey Chadha in an emailed statement, adding that "smaller regional supermarket chains and independents will bear the most pain."Kroger, which plunged 19% Thursday after warning on full-year earnings, sank 9.2% on Friday to a two-year low.Wal-Mart, Costco and Target shares also were big losers, along with dollar stores and drugstores with significant grocery operations. Sprouts Farmers Market was down 6.3% after losing 9.4% Thursday.Wal-Mart has been seen as a growing Amazon competitor online, reporting revived e-commerce growth in recent quarters and making several initiatives such as curbside delivery and discounts for in-store pickups. It's also made several online acquisitions, announcing Friday that it will buy Bonobos, an upscale online men's apparel site, for $310 million.But UBS' Lasser said the Amazon news may have a more limited impact on Costco and specialty stores."COST's limited assortment, low cost structure, and deep private label penetration probably means that its fortunes will be preserved, at least for the foreseeable future," Lasser wrote. "Further, the dollar stores like DG and DLTR tend to serve a customer segment that lives in rural areas or has limited resources or looking for a fill in trip. Thus, those models may not see as much change as is feared."RELATED:Amazon Is Buying Whole Foods For $13.7 Billion, Roiling SectorAmazon-Whole Foods Merger Could Be 'Category Killer' For Food, EateriesCould Trump-Bezos Tension Imperil Amazon-Whole Foods Deal?Amazon's Next Big Growth Play Will Surprise You

XSellers were in high-profile technology stocks again Thursday as Wall Street pondered the implications of Wednesday's rate hike by the Fed and a policy statement that many interpreted as slightly hawkish.The so-called FANG stocks were under pressure again, although losses were contained. Netflix (NFLX) looked poised for its fourth-straight close below the 50-day moving average as shares fell 1%. Facebook (FB), Amazon.com (AMZN) and Alphabet (GOOGL) were also lower as all three hold slightly above their 50-day lines.Alphabet slipped 1% but was near session highs after Canaccord Genuity downgraded shares to hold from buy but maintained a 1,000 price target.The Nasdaq composite was down 0.5%, trimming a 1.4% intraday loss; the S&P 500 eased 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.1%. Volume on both exchanges was tracking close to Wednesday's levels in the stock market today.Some fast-growing China growth names also look vulnerable. JD.com (JD) slid 2% as it threatens a break below the 50-day line. TAL Education (TAL) was on pace for its third-straight decline as it seeks support at the 50-day line.Outperformers in the Dow included Procter & Gamble (PG), Boeing (BA) and Caterpillar (CAT), with gains of more than 1%.Inside the IBD 50, Coherent (COHR) was on pace for its fifth-straight decline, but the stock moved off session lows after touching the 50-day line. Veeva Systems (VEEV) has also been firming up at the 50-day line in recent days.Grocery store chains were weak across the board after Kroger (KR) reported earnings and cut its full-year earnings guidance. Shares cratered 19%.In economic news, soft retail-sales data for May, released Wednesday, was followed up by decent manufacturing data Thursday. The Philadelphia Fed Business Outlook Survey clocked a reading of 27.6, slightly ahead of expectations. Meanwhile, the Empire State manufacturing survey came in at 19.8, well above the Econoday consensus estimate of 5.0.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, benchmark U.S. crude oil fell 0.6% to $44.47 a barrel. The 10-year Treasury yield rebounded after Wednesday's drubbing, rising 4 basis points to 2.16%.RELATED:4 Strong Biotechs That Need To Go On Your Watchlist Now Kroger Dives After Slashing Earnings Outlook Amid Grocery Price WarAmazon Price-Target Hike Supported By Growth In New Businesses

Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) shares shot up as much as 16% after its third-quarter earnings and revenue grew more than anticipated, while archrival Whole Foods Market's (WFM) quarterly earnings tanked.
Organic and natural foods grocer Sprouts said early Thursday that Q3 earnings per share minus one-time items rose 17% vs. Q3 2014 to 21 cents, beating analyst estimates by 2 cents a share.
That beat surprised some after Sprouts just met Q2 EPS estimates and missed in Q1.
Q3 revenue climbed 18% to $903.1 million, topping consensus of $896.8 million. Comparable store sales grew 5.8%, and Sprouts announced a $150 million share buyback.
"Top-line sales increased through strong promotions and operational execution, which drove increased customer traffic trends," Sprouts CEO Amin Maredia said in an earnings statement.
The company forecast full-year 2015 diluted EPS of 83 to 84 cents, above consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for 81 cents.
Sprouts shares closed up 15.7% to 23.01 in Thursday afternoon trading on the stock market today, pushing it above its 50-day average, though it was still below its 200-day.
After the rise Thursday, it was still down about 40% from a 38.38 2015 high close, set Feb. 13, as competition in the sector heats up.

Kroger (KR), the nation's largest supermarket operator under its namesake, as well as Ralph's, Fred Meyer and other brands, has boosted the number of natural foods it carries in recent years and rolled out its own natural-foods brand, "Simple Truth."
Kroger is estimated to sell $11 billion of natural and organic products a year, making it the nation's second biggest retailer of such products, surpassed only by Whole Foods Market.
Late Wednesday, Whole Foods Market, with about $15.4 billion annual sales, reported fiscal Q4 EPS and revenue that both fell far below Wall Street targets and guided below consensus.

Whole Foods co-CEO John Mackey told analysts on an earnings call: "After appearing to stabilize early in the quarter, our comps moderated over the last nine weeks, driven by changes in both traffic and basket size. Our EPS miss was driven in large part by weaker-than-anticipated sales ..."
Kroger shares ended up 0.2%, and Whole Foods fell 2.1%.

Sprouts, Whole Foods and Kroger are also getting competition from Amazon (AMZN), which sells groceries online and operates a grocery home-delivery service, and big-box retailer Costco Wholesale (COST), which Fortune said in an Oct. 28 report sells about $4 billion a year in organic and natural foods.
Amazon, an IBD Leaderboard list stock, rose 2.3%. Costco lost 0.6%.

Marquee names in the retail industry gave ETF investors something to be thankful for this week. Lowe's (LOW) hammered out financial growth. Home Depot (HD) and Wal-Mart (WMT) came off looking good too, ahead of Black Friday. The consumer discretionary sector is leading Q3 earnings growth, which is expected to continue in 2016, says a recent S&P Capital IQ report.…
Facebook (FB), Whole Foods Market (WFM) and 21st Century Fox are among the notable companies reporting quarterly results on Wednesday. Here's a look at what to expect.

Analysts expect social-media pioneer Facebook's third-quarter earnings per share to surge 21% from a year ago to 52 cents on revenue up 36% to $4.367 billion, both accelerations from the prior quarters.

The company over the past year has made all its public posts searchable, tried to recast itself into a more news-centric site, and rapidly expanded in video for users and advertisers — developing an array of new video features to deepen user engagement.

The site's users are viewing around 4 billion videos a day, Jefferies said in a research note last month, and the investment firm expects video ads to become a multibillion-dollar business over the next two years as digital ad formats become more expensive.

"As video consumption explodes across FB's massive user base, we think FB looks well positioned to capture an increasing portion of TV ad budgets as marketers migrate toward data-driven, highly targeted online video ad campaigns," Jefferies said. The firm also said that Facebook app Instagram, with its "beautiful visual layout" and "highly engaged audience" would make for a good advertising environment.
Shares closed down 0.7% to 102.58 in the stock market today.

Upscale grocery chain Whole Foods has struggled with its "whole paycheck" reputation, allegations that it overcharged consumers and competition from traditional grocery chains like Kroger (KR), which have pushed more aggressively into Whole Foods' turf by offering higher-quality fare.
Whole Foods in September said it would lay off 1,500 workers, partly to keep prices lower and invest in technology.
Whole Foods is trying to draw younger shoppers with less disposable income by launching a new chain of stores called 365 by Whole Foods Market. Those stores are set to open next year.
Analysts expect Whole Foods' Q4 EPS to fall around 3% to 34 cents. Sales are seen rising 7% to $3.470 billion, both slowing from the prior two quarters. Shares rose 1.1% to 31.27.

Two media giants reporting Wednesday, 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Time Warner (TWX), have been pressured by the rise of online programming from services like Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon (AMZN) Prime Video. Investors will be tuned into the companies' ad sales, subscriber figures, and other signs of how they've adapted to the digitization of television.
Analysts see 21st Century Fox's Q1 EPS slipping 5% to 37 cents, with revenue edging down to $6.422 billion. Time Warner's Q3 EPS is expected to fall 12% on revenue up 4% to $6.512 billion.
Time Warner shares rose 1% to 77.30; Fox rose 1.4% to 31.28.
Two pharmaceutical companies, Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) and Allergan (AGN), also report Wednesday.

Botox maker Allergan's Q3 EPS is seen falling by a cent to $3.18. The Street forecasts sales rising 10% to $4.033 billion. That gain, while strong, pales in comparison to the prior quarter, when sales jumped 116% after Actavis acquired the company in March.
Regeneron's third-quarter EPS is expected to leap 27% to 3.20, with sales lifting 45% to $1.054 billion.
Regeneron's drug for failing eyesight, Eyelea, has propelled the company's growth. Its drug Praluent, an injectable PCSK9 inhibitor co-developed with Sanofi (SA), launched this summer.

A "(special) focus is expected to be given to initial figures from the Praluent launch," Roth Capital Partners said of Regeneron's upcoming quarterly results. "As we noted in our previous note, we expect a gradual launch, though we eventually expect Praluent and Repatha to achieve blockbuster status. We believe doctors will first look to optimize statin therapy and other modalities like Merck's (MRK) Zetia/Vytorin before moving to an injectable therapy."
Regeneron shares fell 0.2% to 578. Allergan fell 1.8% to 309.31.

Electronic payments processor First Data plans to raise $3 billion in what is set to be the largest initial public offering this year. First Data, which KKR (KKR) took private eight years ago for $25.6 billion, is offering 160 million shares at 18 to 20. That would value First Data at about $17.6 billion. It's among seven IPOs planned for this week.
The IPO would surpass Tallgrass Energy (TEGP) as the largest this year. Tallgrass raised $1.2 billion when it priced 41.5 million shares at 29 on May 6.

First Data provides a range of credit card and electronic payment processing services, among other services such as fraud prevention, for banks, merchants and financial institutions. In 2014, it processed 74 billion transactions globally, the company said. In 2014, First Data reported revenue of $11.2 billion and a net loss of $458 million.
First Data is set to begin trading Thursday on the NYSE under the ticker FDC. The lead underwriters are Citigroup (C) and Morgan Stanley (MS).
Albertsons IPO Also Over $1 Bil

The second-largest initial public offering this week — and this year — comes from supermarket chain Albertsons, which is set to raise $1.6 billion. It will offer 65.3 million shares at 23 to 26 each, giving it a fully diluted market value of about $11.9 billion.

Albertsons is the third-largest U.S. grocery store chain, behind Wal-Mart (WMT) and Kroger (KR). An investment group led by Cerberus Capital Management bought Albertsons nine years ago and combined it with Safeway, acquired for $9.4 billion last March. The company operates 2,205 stores across 33 states.
Albertsons is set to begin trading Thursday on the NYSE under the ticker ABS. The lead underwriters are Goldman Sachs (GS) and BofA Merrill Lynch.

Also on the IPO docket this week is Adesto Technologies, a provider of flash memory chips intended for connected devices, also known as the Internet of Things. Adesto plans to raise $45 million by offering 4.1 million shares at 10 to 12.

Adesto follows the tech IPO of Pure Storage (PSTG), a provider of data storage devices based on flash memory chips for the enterprise market. Pure Storage raised $425 million with its IPO last week, offering 25 million shares at 17. Pure Storage stock was up 10% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, above 18.
Adesto is scheduled to begin trading Friday on the Nasdaq under the ticker IOTS.

The third-largest IPO this week is American Farmland, which plans to raise $114 million by offering 12 million shares at a range of 8.50 to 10.50. The company is a real-estate investment trust that owns farmland in California, Illinois and Florida. American Farmland is scheduled to begin trading Friday on the NYSE under the ticker AFCO.
IPOs Were Delayed A Week
Three other IPOs this week are holdovers from last week. They are Stonebridge Biopharma, SynCardia Systems and Cerecor.

Stonebridge Biopharma looks to raise $76.5 million, offering 4.25 million shares at a price of 18. It trades on the over-the-counter market in Norway. Stonebridge is developing therapies for rare endocrine disorders. It will list on the Nasdaq under the ticker SBBP.

SynCardia Systems looks to raise $28 million, offering 2.5 million shares in the range of 10 to 12. SynCardia is a medical technology company focused on developing an implantable system designed to assume the full function of a failed human heart in patients with advanced heart failure. It will list on the Nasdaq under the ticker TAHT.
Cerecor plans to raise $27 million, offering 4.2 million shares at 6 to 7. Cerecor is developing therapies for depressive disorders. It will list on the Nasdaq under the ticker CERC.
A trading date for all three is listed as day to day.

XStocks opened down Thursday as the brutal selloff in technology stocks continued. The Nasdaq dropped 1%, while the S&P 500 moved down 0.5%. The Dow Jones industrial average only traded down 0.3%.Among the Dow industrials, Caterpillar (CAT) and Boeing (BA) paced the advancers with gains of 0.9% and 0.5%.In early trading, Apple (AAPL) joined Nike (NKE) and Visa (V) at the bottom of the early morning's performers. Apple dropped 1%, while Nike declined 2.3%. Visa fell 1.2%.Within the S&P 500, truck manufacturer Paccar (PCAR) moved up 1.1%, but remains stuck under its 50-day line.On the downside, grocery store Kroger (KR) plummeted over 12% after cutting its full-year guidance during its Q1 earnings results. Toy maker Mattel (MAT) was cut to neutral at DA Davidson, sending shares down 7%.Among leading stocks in the stock market today, Tesla (TSLA) and Nvidia (NVDA) both fell sharply, but were paring their losses. The maker of electric automobiles dropped 2.5% after reaching a new record high Wednesday, while the graphics chip maker is trading about 10% off its all-time highs, declining just over 1% Thursday morning.FANG stocks were hit hard early Thursday as the selloff in technology names continued in earnest. Facebook (FB) and Amazon.com (AMZN) fell almost 2%, while Netflix (NFLX) declined 1.6%. Amazon.com had its price target raised to 1,100 from 975 at Nomura Instinet.Google-parent Alphabet (GOOGL) was downgraded to hold at Canaccord Genuity, which had concerns about future growth. Shares fell 2.4% as the stock attempted to cling to its 50-day moving average.China stocks also sold-off. E-commerce giants Alibaba (BABA) and JD.com (JD) fell 1.9% and 3.5%, respectively, while gamer NetEase (NTES) traded down 2.2%.Action in the IBD 50 was predominantly negative, but regional banks were rare brights spots. Citizens Financial (CFG) and East West Bancorp (EWBC) moved up 0.2% apiece.On the downside, YY (YY) lagged with a near 6% decline. GrubHub (GRUB), TAL Education (TAL) and Momo (MOMO) all fell more than 3%.RELATED:Amazon PT Raised To 1,100; Alphabet, GrubHub DowngradedKroger Stock Dives After Slashing Profit Outlook Below ConsensusDow Jones industrial average And Dow Stocks: News And AnalysisFANG Stocks News & Quotes: Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google

The Dow Jones industrial average rose modestly even as big techs such as undercut the Nasdaq. The Federal Reserve raised interest rates and gave surprisingly hawkish outlook amid weaker economic data. Amazon (AMZN) agreed to buy Whole Foods (WFM). Apple (AAPL) confirmed it's entering autonomous driving field, while video game industry giants showed off at E3. Oil prices crashed amid a continued global supply glut.After a nasty reversal June 9, leading techs such as Apple and Facebook (FB) continued to push the Nasdaq lower, partly due to a hawkish Fed and reports that President Trump is being investigated. The Nasdaq sank 0.9% for the week, though it found 50-day support on Thursday. The Dow industrials rose 0.5%, hitting all-time highs despite weakness in tech components such as Apple and Microsoft (MSFT). The S&P 500 index edged up a fraction despite losses among techs, energy stocks and grocery chains. Grocers tumbled on Amazon's deal to buy Whole Foods Market and warnings and gloomy news from Kroger (KR) and Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM). Treasury yields hit 2017 lows, but rebounded somewhat.Amazon announced Friday that it will buy the brick-and-mortar natural foods grocer for $13.7 billion in a deal that would change the landscape for grocery stores, Amazon, e-commerce and retail overall. The news roiled grocery stores already reeling from food price deflation due to Wal-Mart (WMT) and Amazon. Kroger on Thursday issued a full-year profit warning as it vowed not to be beaten on price. Kroger, Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) and Supervalu plunged for the week. Big grocery sellers Wal-Mart, Costco (COST), Target (TGT), CVS Health (CVS) and Dollar Tree (DLTR) also tumbled Friday.RELATED:Amazon Is Buying Whole Foods For $13.7 Billion, Roiling SectorThe Federal Reserve hiked its key interest rate on Wednesday, as expected, but unnerved Wall Street by shifting its policy outlook in a more hawkish direction even as core consumer price inflation hit a 2-year-low. Ahead of the Fed meeting, market participants weren't expecting a subsequent rate hike for a year, but Fed policy committee member projections pointed to one more hike in 2017 and three hikes in 2018. The Fed also teed up a plan to begin unwinding financial-crisis-era asset purchases later this year that struck analysts as "fairly aggressive" vs. expectations.The Fed stuck by its economic model showing that low unemployment will feed through to faster wage growth and higher inflation, even as incoming data are raising doubts about that model on Wall Street.RELATED:Fed Hikes Rates, But Hawkish Tone Unnerves MarketsMicrosoft (MSFT) launched its powerful Xbox One X, formerly known as Project Scorpio. But it's unclear how many units will sell this holiday season, given the $499 price tag. Meanwhile, Sony (SNE) PlayStation debuted a number of VR titles. Nintendo (NTDOY) dominated buzz among E3 attendees, and Goldman Sachs (GS) sees Nvidia (NVDA) benefiting from higher sales of Nintendo's Switch consoles. Facebook's Oculus wasn't at the video-game expo as some industry pros see virtual reality taking a breather this year. But Facebook demonstrated its live-streaming capabilities and AR filters.RELATED:E3 2017: Video Games, Virtual Reality, Entertainment NewsCEO Tim Cook finally confirmed that Apple (AAPL) is investing heavily on technology for self-driving cars after years of rumors and unconfirmed media reports. In an interview with Bloomberg, he declined to say whether Apple will make its own car or just produce technology for automakers. Cook called the initiative "the mother of all AI projects." Meanwhile, General Motors (GM) said it is more than tripling its self-driving test fleet. GM CEO Mary Barra said 130 advanced Chevrolet Bolt cars will soon join an existing lineup of 50 first-gen electric vehicles that are being tested.RELATED:Apple Finally Confirms Its Worst-Kept SecretApple Might Have To Make Car To Succeed In Autonomous DrivingMay consumer price inflation data from the Labor Department showed broad weakness in prices for airline tickets, apparel, new and used autos and medical care. Overall, the CPI fell 0.1%, with the year-over-year again moderating to 1.9%. Core prices, stripping out volatile food and energy categories, rose 0.2%, but the annual gain backtracked to 1.7%, lowest since May 2015.May retail sales slid 0.3% — overall and excluding the stalling auto sector — defying expectations of mild gains. Sales at nonstore retailers led by Amazon (AMZN) continued to be the standout category, rising 10.2% from a year ago as department store sales slid 3.7%.Meanwhile, industrial production was weak in May, but the Philly Fed and New York Fed reported stronger-than-expected regional manufacturing activity in June.May housing starts unexpectedly fell, putting further pressure on housing stocks that had been moving to new highs.U.S. crude futures fell 2.4% to $44.74 a barrel, hitting seven-month lows, amid more evidence that a global supply glut continues despite the OPEC production cut. The International Energy Agency said crude stockpiles jumped by 18.6 million barrels in OECD countries in April, pushing the five year average higher than before OPEC's production deal in November. U.S. crude supplies fell in the latest week, the Energy Information Administration said, but by less than expected. Gasoline supplies unexpectedly rose. Domestic production rose to 9.33 million barrels per day up from 9.318 million barrels. And the EIA predicted that it sees U.S. output from 7 major shale basins jumping by 127,000 barrels a day in July, with the biggest increase coming from the Permian basin. Also OPEC's own production climbed 1% to 32.14 million barrels in May on increases from Libya, Nigeria and Iraq. Domestic production rose to 9.33 million barrels per day up from 9.318 million barrels.General Electric (GE) said health care chief John Flannery will take over from current CEO Jeff Immelt on Aug. 1. Immelt pivoted the industrial conglomerate from financial services back to its engineering roots while sharpening its technology focus, but GE stock has fallen roughly 30% since he took over in 2001. General Electric indicated its digital push will continue under Flannery. The Dow component also announced more executive changes later in the week, including the exit of power unit veteran Steve Bolze. That spurred talk of a potential brain drain – similar to exits by losing CEO candidates when Immelt was named CEO in 2000, replacing Jack Welch. GE shares jumped 3.6% Monday.Uber Technologies CEO Travis Kalanick will take an indefinite leave of absence following an independent review of allegations against the ride-hailing company of harassment, discrimination and an aggressive culture. The investigation by Eric Holder, the former U.S. attorney general, led to 47 recommendations and creating a board oversight committee. During an all-staff meeting to discuss how Uber plans to transform itself, director David Bonderman made a comment seen as offensive to women, leading to his resignation.Shares of Dow components Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) and Merck (MRK) diverged Monday on news stemming from trials. A study showed J&J's diabetes medicine Invokana also cut down on cardiovascular events. J&K rose 2.1% for the week to a new high. Merck halted enrollment in two cancer trials after seeing more deaths in patients treated with immuno-oncology drug Keytruda vs. other combinations. Merck stock fell 2.2%.Hawaiian Holdings (HA) crashed after United Airlines (UAL) said it would add service to Hawaii later this year. Stifel analyst Joseph DeNardi downgraded the stock to "sell," saying that Hawaiian Airlines' parent, while performing well, had also benefited from a "very benign" competitive environment.Cheesecake Factory (CAKE) shares nosedived after the sit-down restaurant chain cut its same-store sales guidance, citing signs of "uncertainty on the part of many consumers" and "unfavorable weather that reduced patio usage" in the East and Midwest.Citigroup (C) predicted weaker second-quarter trading revenue, citing low volatility vs. 2016's Brexit and U.S. election season. Citi's forecasts follow similar ones about trading from JPMorgan (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and others. Citi fell 0.9% for the week, holding in a buy zone.

Stocks opened down hard on Thursday, with tech stocks leading the early selling as analyst actions and economic news each played roles in the market's early declines.The Nasdaq tanked 1.2%, while the S&P 500 dropped 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average shed 0.4%.The four FANG stocks all opened down more than 1%. Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) fell furthest, down 1.7%, following a downgrade by Canaccord Genuity to hold from buy.Semiconductor industry groups, fiber-optic telecom groups, data storage and enterprise software stocks were among the hardest hit industries Wednesday. At Thursday's open, key chip names including Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) and IBD 50 stock Nvidia (NVDA) were down 3%.On the Dow, Apple (AAPL) sank more than 1%, but Nike (NKE) tumbled 2.2%, the index's biggest opening loss, after announced a company realignment focusing on 12 key global cities expected to represent 80% of the athletics wear maker's growth through 2020.  The changes include a mangement shuffle and a 2% reduction of hte company's total global workforce.Dow-listed chipmaker Intel (INTC) shed 0.5%. The company announced late Wednesday it had received approval from Israeli trade authorities for its proposed, $15 billion acquisition of Mobileye (MBLY). Mobileye shares rose a fraction in early trade.Chip equipment maker Ichor Holding (ICHR) trimmed its early loss to 2%. The IBD 50 stock has pulled back 25% from its high, set on Friday, but still trading 146% above its December IPO price.Grocery chain Kroger (KR) tanked 13% after beating first-quarter revenue estimates and meeting expectations on its earnings line, but cutting its full-year earnings outlook to below consensus estimates.  Restaurant Bob Evans (BOBE) traded 3%lower following its fourth-quarter report.United Continental Holdings (UAL) traded down 0.8%, after an independent marketing survey found 53% of consumers surveyed said they were less willing to buy a ticket from United following the company's recent controversial treatment of passengers. United shares are pulled back for a test of support at their 10-week moving average, 7% below their June 2 high.First-time unemployment claims eased to 237,000 during the week ended June 10, the Labor Department estimated. That was down from 245,000 claims in the prior week, and better than the mild downtick to 243,000 claims expected by economists.Manufacturing activity fell off sharply — as expected — in the mid-Atlantic region this month. The Philadelphia Federal Reserve reported its Manufacturing Business Outlook Survey dived to 27.6 in June, down from May's 38.8 showing, but still above consensus views for a reading of 26.The New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Survey went the other direction, rebounding to 19.8 in June from a minus 1 tally in May.  Economists had projected a much more mild bounce, to a reading of 5.0.On a national level, industrial production was flat in May, the Federal Reserve reported, below consensus expectations for a 0.2% increase after a 1.1% expansion in May. utilization of manufacturing capacity eased to 76.6% for the month, down from 76.8% and below forecasts for a 'no change' reading.The June builders confidence index is due out from the National Association of Home Builders at 10 a.m. ET.In currency trading, the dollar traded higher on the heels of the Fed's rate hike Wednesday. Gold dropped 1.6% to below $1,256 an ounce. Bonds traded lower, lifting the 10-year yield 3 basis points to 2.15%.Overseas, China's markets ended mixed, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng index taking a 1.2% loss. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 slipped 0.3%.Europe's markets compounded their early losses in afternoon trade, with London's FTSE 100, the CAC-40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX all down more than 1%.RELATED:This Hot Sector Has Stocks In Buy Range: Investing Action PlanIs It Time To Short Apple? Know These 5 Short Selling Rules First

Greg Steltenpohl is a pioneer in the nonalcoholic beverage industry. And he has advice for the entrepreneur who thirsts to make it big. If you want to win in a product category, study hard and truly grasp what your competitors do.Then go out and create something unique. Or make the product a different way.That advice from the head of Califia Farms may be easy to swallow, yet it's hard to do.How does one get started on the right path and do both things well?The CEO revs up his team by inspiring it to imagine, think, design and execute steps into the future."At Califia we're trying to build innovation and kind of asking the question about the question after the question," Steltenpohl told IBD. "We're trying to build that kind of culture of inquiry into everything that we do. And when you apply that type of cultural attribute to fundamental business aspects like manufacturing, it emerges as a core strategy."Sweet TriumphsSteltenpohl knows about success in the tough field of beverages.He turned the U.S. fruit and vegetable juice market on its head after co-founding the Odwalla brand in 1980. That firm focused on minimally processed juice. He sold it to Coca-Cola (KO) in 2001 for $181 million, worth $242 million today.Steltenpohl is doing it again, this time via 5-year-old Pasadena, Calif.-based Califia Farms, which he co-founded with Sun Pacific.Califia has become a giant in almond milk, one of the fastest-growing niches in the food and beverage industry. How does Califia take Steltenpohl's advice to heart?When he started the company in 2010 and began production in 2011, he re-entered the citrus juice market. In his eyes, since citrus is the No. 1 beverage-flavoring agent in the world, Califia could not become a serious player without having at least one product in that category.So his team pondered this point: What could grow to become as popular as orange juice?They decided to develop a market in specialty flavors such as mandarin orange and clementine.Four years later, according to Steltenpohl, Califia is the country's largest producer of tangerine juice.Califia created California Lemonade with its different taste. "The Meyer lemon has 10% to 15% less acid (than other lemon types). It has a much rounder flavor, and so you can lower the sugar content (and) increase the drinkability and the (beneficial) effects on people's stomachs," Steltenpohl said.Soon he moved into almond milk. Before making a single quart, his team thought hard about how to approach the market.Here's To Improvement"We weren't the first to market. Our thought process was, 'How can you make it better? How can you leapfrog where the pack is and really make something that provides a benefit and is not simply another brand?'" Steltenpohl said.His solution was to reinvent the manufacturing process. Large almond milk makers cook up the nuts with heat and oil, then mix the resulting butter with water.Such a process creates oxidized byproducts, affecting taste.In contrast, Steltenpohl uses a method that he equates to recipes that date back to the Middle Ages.Rather than heat the almonds, Califia artisans blanch the skin off, make what Steltenpohl calls soaked milk flour, and then apply filtering steps. "This allows us to place more almonds per ounce than most of our competitors and come up with an ultracreamy, velvety mouth feel without traditional food science techniques and lots of gums and binders," he said.Califia continues to innovate with products that range from almond-milk-based horchata to Double Espresso Pure Cold Brew Coffee With Almondmilk to agua fresca drinks with flavors such as watermelon, strawberry, mango, basil, ginger and chili lime.As of July, Califia products are in 27,000 retail outlets, including Kroger (KR), Safeway, Wal-Mart (WMT), Whole Foods (WFM), Gelson's Markets, Fresh & Easy and Stater Bros.Steltenpohl forecasts annual sales to hit $100 million in 2016."Greg is a once-in-a-lifetime leader with whom to work," said Kaitlin Walter, a Califia marketing officer who joined the firm after a stint at Coke. "Greg takes everyone's point of view seriously, weighing the various opinions from his team carefully before making executive decisions. He encourages all Califia employees to think creatively and out of the box, both by example and through encouragement."Big MoneyFurther growth looks likely. On Sept. 15, Califia announced a $50 million investment by Stripes Group, a New York equity firm focused on consumers and tech.While almond milk industry sales are growing at a 40% annual clip, according to a report in May by market researcher Packaged Facts, Califia's Almondmilk brand enjoys 177% yearly growth.Dan Marriott, managing partner at Stripes, calls Steltenpohl a "true product visionary" and adds, "Greg is assembling an amazing team and has cultivated a culture of rapid innovation focused on delivering premium, healthful products."Steltenpohl, 60, has lived near oranges his entire life. During childhood, his family moved from Homestead, Fla., to Southern California's Highland area, once a hotbed of orange growth."My father always picked houses away from people and near orange groves, so I was raised near the smell of orange blossoms," he said. "This made a deep imprint on me. So when I was just out of college and broke, making fresh squeezed orange juice just made sense."That college was Stanford, where he says he was the first to design and complete an undergraduate degree in environmental studies.After college, he joined two partners to start Odwalla as a simple business, selling fresh-squeezed orange juice out of a van in Santa Cruz, Calif. The idea was to offer something of premium quality.Sales grew, and Odwalla expanded outside of California by 1994.Two years later, an outbreak of E. coli bacteria contaminated a batch of apple juice shipments. Odwalla juice used blemished fruit, killing a child and sickening 66.It was not only tragic but also a public relations disaster. Sales dropped 90%, according to a Harvard Business School case study published in 1997. In 1998, Odwalla agreed to pay $1.5 million and admit guilt to charges of selling contaminated juice.Steltenpohl learned that to prevent such a calamity from recurring, a leader must have operating principles in place for factory workers to report any problems directly to top management.Steltenpohl is married with three sons, all of whom work in the beverage industry. He carries such passion for his products that he hasn't let a liver transplant several years ago slow his effort to meet with buyers at big trade shows such as Expo West in Anaheim, Calif.Winning WayIt's clear to Steltenpohl that corporate culture is vital."One of the biggest things I learned is that you can use your culture as a significant competitive advantage and as a kind of business systems strategy," he said, adding: "All of a sudden, you're bringing in all sorts of creative opportunities. You're bringing in a higher degree of quality control. And you're bringing kind of an excitement, you're infusing culture with a closeness to the product. I feel all of those pay off in the long run. I learned that at Odwalla, and I've been applying it in spades here at Califia."

The upscale grocer said it will pay affected employees in full during that time as they transition, and it expects a "significant percentage" to…
Weakness in the IPO market continued Thursday, as electronic-payments-processing giant First Data (FDC), the largest new issue this year, struggled to get out the door.

First Data priced late Wednesday at 16, below its estimated range of 18 to 20. The IPO raised $2.6 billion, below plans to raise $3 billion. The stock opened at 16.39 and remained up a fraction much of the day, but closed down 1.6%, at 15.75.
The initial public offering still managed to be the largest this year, surpassing Tallgrass Energy (TEGP), which raised $1.2 billion with its IPO on May 6.

First Data provides a range of credit-card and electronic-payment-processing services, including fraud prevention, for merchants and financial institutions. In 2014, it processed 74 billion transactions globally, the company said. First Data reported revenue of $11.2 billion for 2014, with a net loss of $458 million.
First Data was taken private by KKR (KKR) in a leveraged buyout eight years ago for $25.6 billion.
Signs emerged heading into the IPO that First Data was struggling to attract institutional investors at its price range.

Scott Sweet, senior managing partner at IPO Boutique, was advising clients to remain "extremely cautious" about the deal due to the high level of long-term debt ($20.7 billion) held by First Data, its slow revenue growth and other factors.
"It's a buyer's market, a tough IPO market right now," Sweet told IBD in an interview Wednesday.
Albertsons, SynCardia Hold Off

Another IPO that was scheduled to price Wednesday, supermarket chain Albertsons, was postponed "due to market conditions." Albertsons was set to be the second-largest IPO this year. It planned to raise about $1.6 billion, offering 65.3 million shares at 23 to 26 each.

Albertsons is the No. 3 U.S. grocery-store chain, behind Wal-Mart (WMT) and Kroger (KR). An investment group led by Cerberus Capital Management bought Albertsons nine years ago and combined it with Safeway, acquired for $9.4 billion in March. The company operates 2,205 stores across 33 states.
SynCardia Systems, a developer of implantable artificial hearts, withdrew its plans for an initial public offering on Tuesday.

Of the five IPOs that debuted last week, four priced below their estimated range. The only one that didn't was Pure Storage (PSTG), which priced at 17, the midpoint of its range. Pure Storage, a provider of flash-chip-based storage products for the enterprise market, raised $425 million. The stock closed Thursday at 19.68, down a fraction.

In Q3, the IPO market slowed to 34 deals, down 43% from the year-earlier quarter, says Renaissance Capital, amid a broad market sell-off and the near absence of technology deals. The IPOs raised $5.1 billion, the lowest amount since Q3 2011.

Initial public offerings backed by venture capital also fell sharply in Q3. Thirteen venture-backed IPOs raised $1.75 billion in Q3, a 55% decrease in the number of offerings from Q2 and a 54% decline in the total amount of dollars raised, reports the National Venture Capital Association.

The NVCA says that 50 venture-backed companies have filed with the SEC to make an IPO. Mobile-payment services provider Square filed plans late Wednesday for an IPO. The SEC filing did not include the number of shares to be offered or the price range, which will be determined later.
Jack Dorsey, co-founder and CEO of Twitter (TWTR), is also co-founder and CEO of Square.
