The time when customers paid for their purchases by swiping their credit cards and signing a paper receipt is coming to an end. New cards with a microchip and PIN have made their inroads into the financial payments market. And October 2015 marks an important steppingstone in this transition.

Payment processor Vantiv (VNTV) stands to benefit from this industrywide shift. The Ohio-based company operates on both sides of the same market: It provides a full suite of payment services to merchants on the one hand; and on the other, it produces the physical cards for financial institutions across the U.S.

Thanks to its extensive distribution network and access to both large and small merchants, Vantiv is the second-largest merchant acquirer in the U.S., representing an 18% market share in total payment transactions, overtaking a unit of Bank of America (BAC) in 2014. First Data ranked at the top. Vantiv also ranks as the No. 1 U.S. merchant acquirer in PIN debit transactions. An acquirer is a bank or other institution that accepts card payments in the merchants' behalf.

On the financial services side, Vantiv holds a 10% market share in the U.S., representing more than 1,400 banking and financial customers. "It is the electronic middleman that enables and links electronically retailers and point-of-sale systems to the card brands and to the card-issuing institutions," said Raymond James analyst Wayne Johnson.

Among its clients are Macy's (M), Office Depot (ODP), Kroger (KR), Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), In-N-Out Burger, Wendy's (WEN), Comerica Bank (CMA) and Fifth Third Bank (FITB). More recent additions include Rabobank, Capital One Financial (COF) and the U.S. Postal Service.
Among The Big Processors

The company ranks fourth among 28 names in IBD's Finance-Credit Card-Payment Processing industry group. Other players in the group include Blackhawk Network (HAWK), Total System Services (TSS)and Heartland Payment Systems (HPY). The group itself is ranked No. 29 among IBD's 197 industries.

Originally a spinoff from Fifth Third Bank, Vantiv loaded up on technology and additional distribution capabilities to conquer the fast-growing market of electronic payments. It expanded its growth organically via a strong referral business and inorganically through a few key acquisitions.

As a result, it's been able to grow revenue at a 40%-plus rate for the past nine consecutive quarters. Earnings per share increased 15% to 26% during the past six quarters. Its stock is up 36% so far this year.

The transition to chip cards, or what the industry calls EMV migration, has challenged the industry. October is the target for the so-called "liability shift." After the shift, when a transaction takes place, the party with the weaker technology will bear the cost of the possible hack or fraud.

That's why most national merchants, retailers and banks have been working hard to issue the EMV cards and install EMV card terminals. Those cards carry a chip and are accessible with a PIN instead of the classic magnetic cards that require a signature. The technology embedded in the chip is much more complex; it makes point-of-sale transactions a lot more secure and the cards nearly impossible to duplicate. The chip cards alone do not enhance online payment security, though.

This system has already been in use for many years in Europe and elsewhere in the world. EMV stands for Europay, Mastercard (MA) and Visa (V), the originators of the standard. The U.S. is the last payment market to migrate to it, mostly due to the vastness of the old tech and the cost and complexity of the transition.

The result is that more credit card fraud migrated to the less secure U.S. market over the years. Now that chip cards will enhance the security on that end, the risk may shift to the weaker links in the industry: small and medium-size businesses and online users.
That's where Vantiv comes in.

In addition to being a leader in the EMV transition, Vantiv also has taken steps beyond it. "We think that the best way for the merchants to protect information is to do what we call a security suite of products, which is accepting EMV cards but also encrypting the information and tokenization," said Vantiv CEO Charles Drucker.

Point-to-point encryption helps merchants protect client data. "If the data is encrypted from the point they swipe the card to the point that it's received by us as payment processor ... that data is now protected and virtually impossible to unencrypt, and that's a value-added service we make revenue on," said Andrew Ciafardini, vice president of corporate communications for Vantiv.

The other tool is tokenization, which removes the credit card number completely from the retailer's system. Instead, the retailer gets a representation of the number, which is called a token and is specific to that retailer, Ciafardini explained. "So even if the system were breached, a criminal could not use that token anywhere else."
Growth By Acquisiton

Vantiv has made three acquisitions in recent years. At the end of 2012, it acquired Litle, an independent e-commerce payment processor for Internet and direct-response marketing transactions. Its customer base includes Overstock.com (OSTK), Ancestry.com and Wayfair (W).

"That was a technology-based acquisition," said Nathan Rozof, senior vice president of investor relations at Vantiv. "Today, we're using that e-commerce technology to win clients like the USPS, where they need help processing not only in all their post offices but also USPS.com and the kiosks."

The other two acquisitions relate to the integrated payment space. Whenever a merchant, such as a restaurant, buys the software to manage its orders, inventory, kitchen, employee time and accounting, Vantiv can integrate the payment processing technology and offers 24/7 help lines for all platforms if any issues arise.

Vantiv's purchase of Element in 2013 brought innovative technology into this integrated payment space, while the larger Mercury buyout in mid-2014 brought with it one of the largest distribution channels in the U.S.
More Sales, Cybercrime

The company is certainly benefiting from a positive secular trend. "The macro backdrop has been a positive (for Vantiv), and the declining gas prices have helped fan its sales growth," said Jason Deleeuw, senior research analyst at Piper Jaffray. "We think payment security at the small and midsize merchant level is a key driver of growth for the larger, more sophisticated merchant processors like Vantiv."
Vantiv also plans to use its large cash position to consider offshore acquisitions, grow its core business and return capital to shareholders.

As with any business, there are risks. Analyst Johnson mentions integration risk of its acquisitions, pricing pressure from financial institutions, PIN-network transaction-fee declines and economic risk.

But the company has ambitious plans to grow its market share. From its spinoff in 2009 to today, Vantiv has grown its U.S. payment transactions share from 13% to 18%. "We intend to grow faster than the payments industry," said Rozof.The time when customers paid for their purchases by swiping their credit cards and signing a paper receipt is coming to an end. New cards with a microchip and PIN have made their inroads into the financial payments market. And October 2015 marks an important steppingstone in this transition.Payment processor Vantiv (VNTV) stands to benefit from this industrywide shift. Kroger Co. (KR) lifted its full-year same-store-sales and earnings outlook after posting second-quarter results that sailed past views. The giant grocer's Q2 earnings soared 25.7% to 44 cents a share, beating estimates by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for 39 cents and marking an acceleration in growth from Q1's 15% gain. Sales rose 0.9% to $25.54 billion, ahead of views…

Stocks again opened to narrow losses on Friday, with retail sector stocks experiencing unusually heavy selling. The Nasdaq hurt worst, down 0.9%. The Dow Jones industrial average carved out a 0.7% decline and the S&P 500 fell 0.5%.
Trade was mixed, up 13% on the Nasdaq and 5% lower on the NYSE, compared with action at the same time Thursday
The stock market today felt some early drag from company reports compounded by a raft of weaker-than-forecast producer price and retail sales data.
Business inventories expanded 0.3%, the Commerce Department said, vs. consensus views for no change.

Consumer sentiment offered a bright spot, with the University of Michigan's November Consumer Sentiment Index jumping to 93.1, up from 90 in September and above views for an improvement to 92. It was the index's best reading since July.
In stocks, a number of heavy premarket moves held through to the regular session:

Generic-drug maker Mylan (MYL) surged 8% and Perrigo (PRGO) slumped 8% after Mylan failed in its attempted hostile $26 billion takeover of Michigan-based Perrigo. The Wall Street Journal reported Mylan's cash-for-stock tender offer garnered only 40% of Perrigo shares. Mylan needed at least 50% for a successful takeover. The offer expired at 8 a.m. Friday.

Switzerland-based seed strain and herbicide giant Syngenta (SYT) leapt 7% after a Bloomberg report that the company rejected a $42 billion takeover offer from state-owned China National Chemical Corp. Syngenta refused a $47 billion offer from Monsanto (MON) earlier this year.

Retail groups showed nine of the market's 10 worst losses among industries in the first half hour of trade. Fossil Group (FOSL) collapsed 30%, Nordstrom (JWN) crumbled 18% after reporting weak quarterly results late Thursday.
Video game retailer GameStop (GME) dropped 12%. Grilled chicken chain El Pollo Loco (LOCO) unraveled 13%.

Chip equipment maker Applied Materials (AMAT) climbed 4%. The Santa Clara, Cal. outfit reported in line fiscal Q4 results after Thursday's close. But management said during the quarterly conference call that the company could be open to the possibility of a merger. Applied Materials has been climbing off a September low, but remains deep in an eight-month consolidation.
Leading stocks opened the session in a lousy mood, with more than four in every five stocks on the IBD 50 list losing ground in early action.

China-based TAL Education (XRS) posted the best move in the group, up almost 2% to peck out another new high. The provider of kindergarten through 12th grade after school tutoring services is now nearly 8% past a 38.75 buy point in a cup with handle base.

At the low end of the list, Paycom Software (PAYC) lopped off 7%. The Oklahoma City-based provider of online human-capital management programs priced a 4.5 million share offering at 42.50, a 5% discount to Thursday's closing price. The loss dragged shares back below a 41.68 buy point, but left the stock above its 50-day line of support.

Whole Foods Market (WFM) has named a new chief financial officer, chair of the board, chair of the nominating and governance committee, and five new independent board members, as the upscale grocer slinked by second-quarter revenue estimates after the close. The move comes amid continued business struggles and buyout buzz."We are accelerating our path to enhanced value creation to deliver better returns for our shareholders," said Whole Foods CEO John Mackey in a statement that outlined updated strategic initiatives. "Today's announcement is a powerful combination of accelerated initiatives and new cost savings with clear timelines to deliver. We are on a path to return to positive comparable store sales and earnings growth next year."Incoming CFO Keith Manbeck, who starts in one week, comes from Kohl's (KSS) as senior vice president of digital finance, strategy management and business transformation.Gabrielle Sulzberger, a longtime independent director, was named new chair of the board. Mary Ellen Coe is the grocer's new chair of nominating and governance committee.Among the new independent directors: Panera Bread (PNRA) CEO Ron Shaich, as his bakery-cafe chain recently accepted a buyout from JAB Holdings.The Wall Street Journal reported before the close, citing people familiar the matter, that the board changes were not a settlement with Jana Partners, the activist hedge fund that recently disclosed a sizeable stake in Whole Foods.Estimates: Profit to tumble 16% to 37 cents a share on a 0.8% revenue dip to $3.73 billion. That would be the first sales drop in years.Results: 37 cents per adjusted share on revenue of $3.74 billion. Same-store sales tumbled 2.8%.Outlook: Diluted EPS of $1.30 or greater, vs. prior outlook for $1.33 a share. Revenue growth of 1% or more, down from previous guidance for 1.5% gains. Whole Foods reaffirmed a same-store sales decline of 2.5% or better in fiscal 2017.Stock: Shares rose 2.1% to 37 in late trading after closing down 0.9% to 36.25 in the stock market today. Buyout chatter has lifted the stock in recent weeks, most noticeably on April 10, when shares popped 10% on news of Jana Partners' 8.3% stake in the company and the hedge fund's reported interest in a Whole Foods sale.The stock is up about 18% so far in calendar 2017.Why It Matters: Because of all of the M&A whispers. Ceberus Capital Management-controlled Albertsons is reportedly exploring an acquisition of Whole Foods, according to a late April report from Financial Times. Jana Partners has taken an 8.3% stake in Whole Foods, seeking big changes or a sale. The reported Whole Foods board shakeup could be a preemptive move to fight Jana Partners.Among other takeover news, a Bloomberg report from earlier last month that Amazon (AMZN) had ever-so-briefly internally toyed with the notion of buying out Whole Foods, and an earlier Bloomberg story from March that said Albertsons was in early talks to buy Whole Foods peer Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) and take it private.Sprouts topped estimates when it reported last week, as EPS grew 10% to 33 cents and revenue rose 14% to $1.13 billion. Analysts had expected 30 cents in per-share earnings on $1.11 billion. Sprouts rose 1.3% to 23.63, its best close since July 2016.Grocer sellers from Whole Foods to mainstream giants such as Kroger (KR) to dollar store operators have come under pressure amid food cost deflation, in part due to renewed price cutting by retail giant Wal-Mart (WFM). Wal-Mart is offering curbside pickup while Amazon is expanding its AmazonFresh home delivery. Whole Foods relies on tech unicorn Instacart to provide delivery.RELATED:Whole Foods Shares Up On Report That Albertsons Is Grocery ShoppingThis Stock Is Up On News That Amazon Even Thought About Buying ItWhole Foods Jumps On Jana Stake As Private Equity Eyes Grocers

Whole Foods Market (WFM) shares rallied on a Financial Times report that Albertsons is exploring an acquisition of the natural-foods grocery chain.Albertsons parent Cerberus Capital Management is said to have held preliminary talks with bankers about a potential takeout offer, though no formal bid has been made, said the outlet, citing sources.This is not the first reported takeover chatter in the grocery space that has stemmed from the same private equity firm. Bloomberg said last month that Cerberus-controlled Albertsons was in preliminary discussions to merge with Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) and take the grocer private.Shares of Whole Foods closed 2.1% higher at 36.46 on the stock market today after surging as much as 4.5% intraday, while Sprouts sold off 3.3% on fading hopes for an Albertsons buyout.Discussions between Sprouts and Albertsons have not proceeded, said Financial Times sources.Whole Foods had previously leapt 10% on April 10 after Jana Partners disclosed that it had acquired an 8.3% stake in the company, with a potential goal of nudging it toward a sale.Two days later, reports emerged that Amazon (AMZN) had briefly pondered internally whether to buy Whole Foods, also bumping up shares. Kroger (KR) also has been mentioned as a possible Whole Foods buyer.Since the latest takeover chatter began last month, Whole Foods stock has soared 25%.RELATED:This Stock Is Up On News That Amazon Even Thought About Buying ItWhole Foods Jumps On Jana Stake As Private Equity Eyes Grocers

Shares of Whole Foods (WFM) spiked to their highest level since July after Jana Partners disclosed an 8.3% stake, reportedly with an eye toward pushing the upscale grocer to gauge interest from potential buyers, just weeks after Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) became the subject of takeover talk.In an SEC filing on Monday, Jana and others disclosing a stake said the shares were "undervalued and represent an attractive investment opportunity." The disclosure also said that Jana and the others intended to hold discussions with management about Whole Foods' "chronic underperformance for shareholders."The discussions could also concern potentially shaking up the board and management, "optimizing" its real estate strategy, and addressing weakness in customer loyalty, analytics, and digital and other technology.The Wall Street Journal reported that Jana would try to get Whole Foods to assess how much someone might want to pay to buy the chain.Shares of Whole Foods jumped 10% at 34.17 on the stock market today, shattering through the ceiling of a flat base. Sprouts rose 1.1%, climbing intraday to an eight-month high.United Natural Foods (UNFI), a distributor of natural and organic groceries, crashed 8.2%. Kroger (KR) rose 1.1%.IBD'S TAKE: Whole Foods likely isn't the only company that may have to "optimize" its real estate strategy. The retail sector overall has been seen as having too many stores.Whole Foods has also suffered as Kroger and others that have typically competed more on value stock their own aisles with fresher, higher-quality fare.Even as Whole Foods works to shed its "whole paycheck" reputation with its "365" format, which is more focused on cheaper products, grocery prices have trended lower in recent months, resulting in discounts that shoppers like but that hurt sales.The disclosure comes after Bloomberg last month reported that supermarket operator Albertsons, which is controlled by the private equity firm Cerberus, had engaged in early-stage discussions to possibly combine with Sprouts Farmers Market and take Sprouts private. Kroger was also rumored last year to be interested in buying Whole Foods.RELATED:Kroger Expects Grocery Woes To Continue After Same-Store Sales Fall

Call it a different kind of "Amazon Effect" on retailers: Shares of Whole Foods Market (WFM) rose 1.7% in the stock market today following a report that Amazon.com (AMZN) internally toyed with the idea of acquiring the upscale natural-foods grocery store chain.The notion reportedly didn't take off past the discussion stage, but the idea was that Whole Foods would reinvigorate Amazon's grocery efforts, according to Bloomberg, citing a person familiar with the matter.Whole Foods, with a near-$11 billion market cap, would be a huge challenge for Amazon. But Wal-Mart (WMT) is quickly becoming a serious online rival that is taking advantage of its physical locations. Wal-Mart already offers curbside pickup for online grocer orders and just announced that it will offer discounts for many online orders that are picked up in stores.Activist investor Jana Partners ultimately took an 8.3% stake in the grocer, saying in an SEC filing that Whole Foods shares are "undervalued and represent an attractive investment opportunity," and that it would discuss with management the chain's "chronic underperformance," among other things.That disclosure from Jana, which included the possibility that it might engage in a sale or merger for the grocer, sent Whole Foods shares up nearly 10% on Monday.IBD'S TAKE: Amazon has been plowing into the grocery space for a while now, developing online grocery delivery and reportedly planning to build convenience stores. Amazon shares fell 0.65% to 896.46 on Wednesday, still in range from an 860.96 buy point from a four-weeks tight pattern.Along with Amazon, Kroger (KR) and Albertsons were also names tossed into the mix of Jana's potential bidders, according to Bloomberg, citing sources familiar with Jana's thinking. Kroger rose 1%.Albertsons, controlled by Cerberus Capital Management, reportedly had held preliminary talks with Whole Foods rival Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) in March. Sprouts fell 1.3%.RELATED:Wal-Mart Will Pay You To Pick Up Your Online Orders; Your Move, AmazonKroger Expects Grocery Woes To Continue After Same-Store Sales FallAmazon Pushing Deeper Into Grocery Business With New Store Plans

Online giant Amazon (AMZN) on Tuesday fired another salvo at brick-and-mortar retailers with a new service designed for the time-sensitive shopper who purchases groceries on the internet.Dubbed AmazonFresh Pickup, the offering allows consumers to order groceries online and then collect their purchases from a physical location at a convenient time. So no more waiting in line at the grocery checkout — or even waiting for the delivery truck to show up.Instead, at AmazonFresh-branded pickup locations, a company employee will load shoppers' grocery bags into their cars. There are no purchase minimums and orders can be picked up in as little as 15 minutes, according to the company.The long-rumored move intensifies Amazon's attempts to shake up the U.S. supermarket industry — one of the largest retail segments in terms of total sales, and one of the few where traditional brick-and-mortar companies have been able to successfully defend against competition from online retailers — said Christian Magoon, founder of Amplify Investments."Grocery shopping has the unique issue of consumers wanting to see their food and have it be fresh and to pick it up themselves," Magoon said. "If Amazon gets a foothold there, it will be an incredible growth opportunity for them."However, one equity research firm expects online groceries to be a key driver of accelerating online shopping activity in the years ahead, growing at two times the rate of overall U.S. e-commerce growth. And young Americans are driving the charge in online grocery shopping, according to March 1 report from Cowen and Company.Roughly one in five millennials between the ages of 25 and 34 bought groceries online — more than any other age group, their survey found.The AmazonFresh truck delivery service, now a decade old, helped Amazon make inroads as a grocery brand. However, that service costs $15 a month for delivering groceries to a shopper's doorstep, while AmazonFresh Pickup locations will be free to use.AmazonFresh Pickup is currently in beta testing with employees at two locations in Amazon's Seattle headquarters. It is not yet open to the public.Shares of Amazon punched up 1.1% to close at 856 on the stock market today amid an analyst upgrade and an announcement that the company is set to acquire Souq.com, one of the largest e-commerce firms in the Middle East.Supermarket rivals Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) and Kroger (KR) also rose Tuesday.The supermarket and mini-market industry group ranks No. 176 out of 197 industry groups tracked by IBD, one of the many segments of the retail sector that is struggling as more and more Americans choose to do most of their shopping online.Magoon's Amplify Online Retail (IBUY), a young exchange traded fund offering exposure to online retailers, has gained 15.33% since its April 2016 inception.By comparison, SPDR S&P Retail, an ETF peer with a hefty stake in brick-and-mortar stores, has given up roughly 9% over the same period.RELATED:Amazon Makes Big Middle East Play With Souq.com Acquisition

Shares of natural foods grocery chain Whole Foods (WFM) rose Monday, potentially due to report that grocery-store operator Albertsons was considering a merger with Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM).Whole Foods also rose last week following a massive run-up for its natural and organics grocer rival last week, although the reasons behind Sprouts' gains were unclear at the time. Friday was a quadruple witching day, during which several options and futures expired.Bloomberg reported on Sunday that Albertsons, controlled by private equity giant Cerberus, had recently held preliminary discussions to potentially merge with Sprouts and take it private. However, no deal was yet in place, and one might not materialize.Sprouts popped at the open, climbing as high as 23.07, but reversed to trade down 0.9% to 21.83 Monday. But that's after soaring 23% last week.Whole Foods rose 1.1% to 29.85 after reaching as high as 30.17 in the stock market today, finding resistance near its 50-day moving average. Whole Foods climbed nearly 4% from Tuesday's intraday low to Friday's close as Sprouts took off.Kroger (KR) was rumored last year to be interested in buying Whole Foods.Whole Foods has struggled as more traditional grocers — such as Kroger — take a page from its playbook, offering more organic and higher-quality fare on their own shelves to compete.But Kroger and other mainstream and value grocers also have struggled in recent months amid broad food price deflation, in part driven by Wal-Mart (WMT). Wal-Mart, a member of the Dow Jones industrial average, is the No. 1 U.S. grocer.Kroger fell 1.2%. Wal-Mart edged up 0.1%.RELATED:Looks Like Sprouts Farmers Market Investors Knew Something After AllKroger Expects Grocery Woes To Continue After Same-Store Sales Fall

Albertsons Cos. has held preliminary takeover talks with Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM), Bloomberg reported Sunday, after Sprouts stock enjoyed its best weekly gain since its initial IPO week 2013.Albertsons, backed by private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, has been in negotiations in recent weeks to take the natural foods grocery private, Bloomberg said, citing sources. Albertsons Cos. owns the Albertsons and Safeway chains.Sprouts surged 23.4% to 22.02 in stock market trading last week, its best post-IPO debut weekly gain and its second-heaviest weekly volume. Sprouts retook its 200-day moving average for the first time in more than nine months. The stock is still in a downtrend that goes back to October 2013, just a few months after the chain came public.There was very little news at the time to explain the stock's advance, which came during a quadruple witching of options and futures contract expirations.The grocery business is under intense pressure. Food price deflation is weighing on natural food chains such as Sprouts and Whole Foods Market (WFM), but also broadline operators such as Kroger (KR) and discounters such as Dollar General (DG) and Target (TGT). Whole Foods Market, after its latest earnings report, said it would close a few locations, the first time it's done that since the recession.Wal-Mart (WMT), the world's largest retailer, is the largest U.S. grocery seller. Wal-Mart, a member of the Dow Jones industrial average, has made a greater effort to push prices lower to boost sales. Wal-Mart also is trying to step up its online grocery offerings, as Amazon (AMZN) and a slew of upstarts try to upend the business.RELATED:Kroger Expects Grocery Woes To Continue After Same-Store Sales FallAmazon Fresh Rival Instacart Valued At $3.4 BillionWhole Foods Market Closing Stores After Weak Sales, Guidance

Alibaba's  (BABA) stock price retreated Monday after the Chinese online marketplace had its price target cut and got a bearish outlook in a report by Barron's, while Kroger (KR) and Marvell Technology (MRVL) also saw analyst action. A Barron's cover story said Alibaba stock could lose an additional 50% of its value. Shares have been on a steady decline…

Investors will get an idea when Kroger, the largest U.S. supermarket chain operator, reports second-quarter results Friday morning. General Mills (GIS) agreed to sell its Green Giant and Le Sueur vegetable businesses to B&G Foods (BGS) for about $765 million cash. The divestitures continue the food giant's drive to cut costs and boost profits. B&G's sales could jump nearly 70% to more than $1.4 billion after the acquisition, based on company data. Last year, B&G reported $848 million…

After last week's strong second-quarter report and raised earnings forecast for the full year, Target (TGT) was cut down Monday with the rest of the stock market. New strategies such as changes in its grocery offerings — more organic, natural and gluten-free products and expanded items such as craft beer and wine to appeal to younger customers — have helped…

If you thought same-day shipping was fast, think again. Amazon (AMZN) just one-upped itself on delivery speed: The e-commerce giant is debuting today its Prime Now mobile app service, which offers one-hour delivery for $7.99 and two-hour delivery for free.Prime Now is now available to Amazon Prime members in the Seattle area, and the company says it is "expanding rapidly" to additional ZIP codes. If you have the app, you can be notified when Prime Now is available in your area.Amazon shares rebounded with the market on Tuesday, ending a 5-session losing streak. The stock retook its 500-day moving average intraday but pulled just below that level by late afternoon, up 4%. The stock is trading about 16% below its all-time high reached a month ago.Amazon boasts that tens of thousands of items can be purchased through Prime Now, including paper towels, wine, beer, milk, ice cream, TVs and Kindle devices. Amazon already has same-day delivery for a variety of items through Amazon Fresh and Amazon dot com, but this is kicking it up a notch.As far as big e-commerce shippers go — including Amazon, Target (TGT), Wal-Mart (WMT) and Google (GOOGL) with its Express service — this is the fastest delivery option yet. But other smaller services, most notably Instacart, are already in the 1-hour delivery game.Instacart specializes in grocery delivery and has partnerships with Whole Foods Market (WFM), Costco (COST) and Kroger (KR)-owned Ralphs, among others.Other services appealing to the on-demand eats space include Uber Eats, GrubHub (GRUB) and Postmates.But right now only Amazon is delivering TVs and other electronics in an hour.Follow Alissa Williams on Twitter: @IBD_AWilliams.

Whole Foods (WFM) sank to a multiyear low in the stock market today on weak quarterly earnings and four analyst downgrades, while Kroger (KR) is trading near highs. The upscale grocer said late Wednesday that comps fell sharply in the last two weeks of the quarter, after officials in New York City said the chain was overcharging customers, adding to…

WhiteWave Foods (WWAV) is broadening its yogurt business with the acquisition of Wallaby Yogurt, and the natural foods maker raised guidance for the year on expectations for "strong growth." The $125 million cash deal for Wallaby is seen closing in Q3 and should be neutral to 2015 earnings, with an earnings lift coming in 2016 and beyond. Wallaby, which makes…

Packaged-food giant General Mills (GIS) reported mixed fiscal third-quarter results Tuesday morningGeneral Mills earnings rose 11% to 72 cents a share, the third straight quarter of improving year-over-year changes and a penny better than expected. Sales declined 5% to $3.79 billion, the seventh straight quarterly slide and slightly worse than forecasts for $3.819 billion. North American retailer sales slid 7%."Our net sales declined due primarily to gaps in pricing and promotional activity in key U.S. businesses. Our cost savings efforts helped us expand our adjusted operating profit margin and drive growth in adjusted diluted EPS.Shares fell 0.8% to 59.76 on the stock market today, outperforming the major averages. The stock has been moving sideways tightly since tumbling in September.Kellogg (K), another big cereals maker, sank 1.9%.General Mills still sees full-year fiscal organic down 4%. Constant currency EPS should climb 5%-7%, but the company said foreign exchange will have an "immaterial" impact on results.General Mills last month cut its full-year earnings and sales forecast, due mainly to weakening U.S. sales outlook for its Yoplait yogurt and Progresso soup, typically high-margin categories Yogurt and soup are typically high-margin categories.Cheaper fresh food prices may be spurring shoppers to buy produce vs. packaged foods from the likes of General Mills and Kellogg. Food price deflation also is squeezing grocers, from Whole Foods Market (WFM) to Kroger (KR) to discounters such as Target (TGT).RELATED:Lennar Hails Post-Election Optimism As Revenue Growth Accelerates

Department stores such as Macy's (M), J.C. Penney (JCP) and Kohl's (KSS) sold off Monday on little news, as investors continue to lower their prospects for traditional retailers as shoppers increasingly shift to Amazon.com (AMZN) and other e-commerce sites.Macy's fell 3.8% to 29.37 on the stock market today, trading at its lowest levels since early February, when takeover buzz began.Kohl's sank 4.8% to 38.56, setting a seven-month low intraday.J.C. Penney retreated 2.3% to 5.85, hitting a five-year low. Regional department store operator Dillard's tumbled 4.5% to 49.79, also hitting its worst levels since early 2012.IBD's Retail-Department Store group, rated dead last out of the 197 industries that IBD tracks, was the biggest losers in Monday's session. Macy's and Kohl's were among the very worst performers on the S&P 500 index Monday.Department stores are working hard to try to be viable, emphasizing their online presence. But Amazon is grabbing a huge share of online sales growth and boasts bigger shipping discounts than even major retailers. Brick-and-mortar chains hope to better-leverage physical stores for online pickups and returns. But at the same time they are slashing their store count. That lowers costs, but calls into question the very omnichannel model they are trying to use to battle Amazon.IBD'S TAKE: Despite their brick-and-mortar woes, traditional retailers are seeing big online sales gains, but from very low levels.Target (TGT) fell intraday to a five-year low, though the retailer closed up 8 cents to 54.37. Target has been lumped in with department stores, especially after its weak Q4 earnings report and guidance.Amazon, for its part, rose 0.55% to 856.99. Amazon is still in buy range from an 821.75 entry and is setting up in a four-weeks-tight pattern with an 860.76 buy point.As for other retailers, Wal-Mart (WMT) isn't doing as badly as some of its rivals. Wal-Mart saw sharp online sales growth over the holidays, with U.S. same-store sales rising. Wal-Mart is re-emphasizing lower prices, a push that's squeezing everyone from Macy's to Target to grocers such as Kroger (KR).Wal-Mart shares closed up 0.1% to 59.98 Monday. But Wal-Mart stock is below its 200-day line and its relative strength line shows the retail giant is an S&P 500 laggard.Off-price retailers such as TJX (TJX) and Burlington Stores (BURL) are near highs, but they too retreated Monday, down 1.3% and 2%, respectively.RELATED:Macy's, Costco, Kohl's And Other Retailers Are Getting SlammedRetailers Face 2017 'Reckoning,' More 'Sad Malls' As Amazon Keeps BoomingTarget Dives To 2014 Levels: 'We're Slow And Have Too Much Inventory'J.C. Penney To Close 130-140 Stores After Mixed Q4, Comp Sales Drop

Stocks opened lower Thursday, reflecting trade across global markets. Investors eyed the highly anticipated initial offering of social networking site Snap (SNAP).The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.1% while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq dropped 0.2%.A strong session Wednesday sent the Dow industrials to their first new high above the 21,000 mark. That left the Dow 5% above its 50-day moving average — the level that has generally been followed by moderate pullbacks since April 2016.The stock market today is riveted on the launch of Snap, which priced its initial offering above expectations at $17 a share Wednesday. Five minutes after the opening bell, trading in the stock had not yet started. That put the market cap of the popular video messaging app near $24 billion, making it the largest tech IPO since China's Alibaba Group Holdings (BABA) in 2014.But Monster Beverage (MNST) was the early newsmaker, surging 13.5% after reporting late Wednesday its fourth-quarter earnings jumped 52%, hurt by distributor termination charges and just shy of analyst targets. A 17% revenue gain handily beat expectations, and management announced a new, $500 million share buyback initiative. Monster has been consolidating and is now back above its 50-day moving average for the first time since August.Broadcom (AVGO) pounded out a 4% advance to new highs. The diversified chipmaker turned in earnings growth of 49% on a 134% rise in revenue for its fiscal first quarter, comfortably above analyst forecasts. Gross margins jumped to 62.4%, up from 60.8% a year ago, and second-quarter revenue guidance was well above consensus views. The IBD 50 and Global Leaders stock is extended past a three-weeks-tight buy point of 208.85.Glaukos (GKOS) soared 10% after a better-than forecast 64% revenue gain and a 114% rise in earnings for its fourth quarter.  The maker of stents used in glaucoma surgery is well extended from a its breakout.China-based JD.com (JD) climbed 4% at the open. The online retailer's fourth-quarter results narrowly beat expectations and guidance was in line with forecasts. The stock ended Wednesday's session still in a buy range above a 29.01 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Anheuser Busch Inbev (BUD) slumped 3% after reporting earnings sharply below expectations in a mixed fourth-quarter report. Shares are attempting to crawl out of a deep five-month consolidation.Grocery chain Kroger (KR) dropped 3% as fourth-quarter sales and earnings narrowly topped consensus forecasts, but comparable-store sales dipped 0.7%.Weekly unemployment claims dropped almost 8%, to 223,000, in the week ended Feb. 25, the Labor Department reported. Economists had projected an increase to 245,000 claims. The four-week moving average contracted to 234,250, a second straight decrease.China's markets declined for a second straight session while, in Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 booked a 0.9% gain as the dollar continued its climb vs. the yen.In Europe, markets remained mixed in afternoon trade, with Frankfurt's DAX and the CAC 40 in Paris up 0.1%, and the FTSE 100 in London battling a fractional decline.RELATED:Snap Worth $24 Billion After IPO Prices Above ExpectationsSnap Debut, JD.com, Kroger, Costco Lead Investing Action Plan

A yawning trench of dirt, wood and exposed cables currently sits at the mouth of the Westfield Century City in west Los Angeles. The Apple (AAPL) store is still open and the Tesla (TSLA) showroom has been moved to a different spot, but much of the shopping center remains under construction.When it reopens this year, it will have expanded into a glamorous 1.2-million-square-foot beast of a mall — 422,000 square feet larger — complete with Italian food emporium Eataly, hip burger joint Shake Shack (SHAK) and "new high-fashion streetside boutiques."XIn fact, the Century City mall won't just be a mall, it will be "an immersive sensory experience unprecedented in the modern retail space," according to a 2015 Westfield press release. This location hardly needs a tuneup. With $1,457 in sales per square foot, it is the ninth-most productive mall in the country, according to a CNBC story from May, citing real estate research firm Green Street Advisors. So why spend $800 million on a makeover?Looks matter more than ever, particularly as social-media bragging rights become an essential part of the millennial shopping experience. So these days, every retailer has to put on a good show, ramping up the drama to boost foot traffic and cheat death as Amazon (AMZN) spells doom for more and more American malls."(Young people are) very into cataloging everything they do via social media, and so these more luxury experiences have more social currency," said Talmage Advisors CEO Liz Dunn.That could mean Snapchatting from inside a Tiffany (TIF) — regardless of whether you buy something — or taking a topside photo of your artisanal lunch. (Never has flat lay photography been so popular.)"Whatever it is, there's a lot more social currency to that than saying 'I'm at a TGI Friday's,' " she said.The mall's transformation into an "immersive sensory experience" contrasts with the post-World War II bloom of malls, which attracted Americans to cookie-cutter hubs with their one-stop-shopping convenience. That has since given way to the splendid isolationism of two-day shipping via Amazon Prime, hollowing out traditional malls and forcing the survivors to become purveyors of experiences that can be shared online.Fellow L.A.-based shopping center The Grove, owned by Caruso, underscores the trend and is a social-media maven's dream.It houses many of the same stores as a regional mall does — like Banana Republic, J. Crew and Anthropologie — but also features a fountain, trolley and live music, helping put it at No. 2 on CNBC/Green Street Advisors' list with a $2,200 in sales per square foot. The photogenic plaza was even once the backdrop for Hollywood-gossip show "Extra," which has no doubt upped its social cred among tourists who want a glimpse of glam."This is where all the B-list celebs, YouTube stars, and Instagram influencers shop (I saw an Instagram male model there myself when I went)," gushed one Yelp reviewer visiting from Toronto.The lure of exclusivity, that close cousin of luxury, is another way retailers have amped up the theatrics.It's a tactic long employed by an athletic-footwear industry that routinely releases shoes in small batches, driving up demand from sneakerheads and high-schoolers alike. There's even a sneaker stock exchange, StockX, devoted to the resale of Jordans, Kobes and anything Kanye has ever designed for Adidas.Other retailers have since caught on. Coach (COH) and Disney (DIS) last year introduced a limited-edition House of Mouse-themed handbag line. Spice Girl-turned-fashion designer Victoria Beckham is behind Target's (TGT) upcoming capsule collection. And H&M seems to have an endless series of designer linkups in the pipeline.The New York Times even declared 2016 "the year of the drop," referring to the slew of limited-edition releases and pop-up shops, like Kylie Jenner's blink-and-it's-gone store, designed to create shopper frenzy.The Hollywood Reporter called the December opening of Jenner's pop-up, located within the Westfield Topanga Mall in Los Angeles' San Fernando Valley, "mayhem."Mayhem is the antithesis of convenience, when it comes to shopping. But that is the point. No one wants to stand in line outside for hours waiting for laundry detergent. A Kylie Lip Kit, however, is not long for this world.To get a teen or 20-something to the mall — and most "drop" shoppers are under 30, noted the Times — the mall must act a little more like a nightclub, velvet ropes and all.Even supermarkets are in on the action: Some Whole Foods Market (WFM), Kroger (KR) and Gelson's locations feature wine bars, a premium add-on meant to keep grocery shoppers in stores longer.Such theater may seem gimmicky, but it works, and is also being seen in actual theaters. The local cineplex, a requisite component of any shopping mall, is also undergoing a revamp.On the defensive from Netflix (NFLX) and massive TVs, theaters have been making screens bigger, audio better, and seats more spacious. And as an alternative to grabbing popcorn from the concession stand and trying to find a decent seat, more theaters now serve cocktails and dinner to your reserved Barcalounger while that summer blockbuster plays in Imax 3D.AMC (AMC), for example, embarked three years ago on a $600 million reseating project to rip out traditional chairs and replace them with recliners.AMC, which has called its collective upgrades a "winning playbook," outlined at a recent presentation that attendance has grown 53% and revenue leapt 70% in its 1,500 or so reseated theaters. It has thousands more theaters in line to be updated.Top exhibitor chain Regal Cinemas (RGC) also recently attributed recent outperformance to plush seating, calling out recliner sites as the "biggest driver.""Theaters have to do something to differentiate themselves from the in-home experience," said RBC analyst Leo Kulp. "That's really what's driven these investments over the past several years."Theaters, full-service restaurants and other bells and whistles have woven themselves into a successful mall's narrative, but it may be a while before the experiential stuff surpasses retail stores that sell shirts and shoes."The future will certainly bring less retail, but it will take a few years to tip the scale" so that retailers become a mall's minority residents, said NPD Group retail analyst Marshal Cohen.There is also some hope for once-reliable mall anchors like Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN), even as Macy's reportedly considers selling itself after a brutal holiday season.The Grove has a Nordstrom, and the revamped Westfield Century City is actually adding a department store to the mix, for a total of three major names. It will now house a two-story Macy's, three-story Bloomingdale's and a three-story Nordstrom that is being relocated from the next mall over.But the massive upgrades being made to shopping arenas could even further widen the gap between top-market malls and their less-moneyed brethren.Of the more-than-1,000 malls in America, the 300 or so top-market "A-malls" account for 75% of mall value (a metric comprised of sales productivity, size and other factors), according to Green Street Advisors.So what's a midtier mall to do? For developers, the answer may be: Change or die.Strong anchors are "imperative" for a shopping center's long-term viability, according to Green Street's 2017 mall outlook report, since income-generating tenants want malls with "vibrant," traffic-driving anchors.As department stores waver, Green Street's research points to restaurants, movie theaters and "traditional power-center tenants" — like Ulta Beauty (ULTA), Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) and pet stores — as rising power players.But Talmage Advisors' Dunn is not optimistic."The problem is, it's a little bit of a self-fulfilling prophesy," she said. "The landlords aren't willing to invest in the lower-tier centers, and the thing that would potentially take a lower-tier center to help it jump a bracket is investment. But it's hard to justify the investment if the center's performance isn't in that top-tier range."

The name Qorvo (QRVO) doesn't mean much to most investors, at least not yet. That's because it's the new name of TriQuint and RF Micro Devices, which have merged. The merger has put the company firmly into the Big Cap 20 this week.
Qorvo makes high-performance radio frequency products that work in mobile devices.
The combined company had triple-digit earnings growth the past few quarters. Analysts are forecasting a 79% year-over-year earnings increase for the current quarter.
Qorvo's trailing four-quarter return on equity is an impressive 40.3%, well above the 17% standard that investors should seek. After-tax margin is 27.3%.

The stock is consolidating. To a novice, it might look like it's formed a cup-with-handle base, but it has consolidated for just six weeks, shy of the seven-week minimum for a proper cup with handle. It may be better to treat the pattern as a cup without handle.

Kroger (KR) might seem an unlikely growth stock. But the operator of grocery stores has redesigned its stores and is offering more organic and natural foods, keeping pace with changing customer tastes and with competitors like Whole Foods Market (WFM).
Whole Foods is another Big Cap 20 member.
Earnings growth at Kroger has accelerated from 17% to 30% to 33%. In the next report, analysts forecast a 12% year-over-year increase in EPS.
Revenue over the past year has run in the high single-digit to low double-digit zone, which is fairly typical for the industry. Return on equity for 2014 was 32.6%, a number boosted by debt.
The grocery store and minimart industry group ranked No. 5 out of 197 industry groups in Monday's IBD — an unusually high position for a typically defensive industry.
Kroger has a five-year annualized EPS growth rate of 17% and boasts steady earnings growth. Its Earnings Stability Factor is 5 on a 0 to 99 scale, where low numbers correspond to steady growth.
O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) broke out of a late-stage base Monday, finishing just above a 214.25 buy point. But volume was below average.
It's another case of accelerating earnings growth, from 18% to 21%, 22% and 26%. Analysts are forecasting a 20% EPS increase for the current quarter.
O'Reilly's five-year annualized EPS growth rate 26%. The company's Earnings Stability Factor is 2.
The company operates more than 4,000 auto parts stores around the nation.
Drugmaker Mylan (MYL) broke out of a flat base last week and has hovered near its 59.70 buy point since then.

And it may be surprising, but the grocery chain's stock has been holding up better during the overall market selloff than the cybersecurity stock and other tech stocks like Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) have.

Some stocks leave the Big Cap 20 for a good reason, as in "too good."

When a stock takes off and then climbs a long way, eventually the long advance makes it less attractive. This is what happened to Southwest Airlines (LUV), which was working on a fifth-stage base when it dropped out of the Big Cap 20 about a month ago.
A late-stage base is less likely to work than a first- or second-stage base mainly because there are too many funds with nice gains in the stock and ready to take profits.

The flip side of that involves stocks that have more of a rolling, sideways look. This kind of action can reset base counts. While that may sound like a technicality, the action reflects weak holders being pressured out of a stock.
You want the stock to be left with strong holders, so that a breakout doesn't immediately roll over.
There's no guarantee, of course, that such stocks will work or even present a valid buying opportunity, but investors should monitor the situation closely.

After hitting a high in November 2013, Starbucks (SBUX) had been wearing out the lukewarm holders with repeated consolidations that corrected in the 12% to 17% range. The rebounds off the lows were moderate, never exceeding the 2013 high until recently.

The stock gapped up out of a first-stage pattern Jan. 23 in fast trade. So far, the advance hasn't gone further than 12% from the 84.30 buy point. This means the next pattern could be first stage, too.
Even if the stock rises the required 20% to make the next pattern second stage, that's still bullish territory.
Starbucks grew earnings 18% to 22% over the past four fiscal years. (The fiscal year ends in September.) The Street expects EPS to grow 18% this fiscal year and again 18% in fiscal 2016.
Recent earnings revisions have been upward.

Pretax margin was 18.9% last year, the highest in at least nine years. Lower commodity prices helped, but so did price increases. Starbucks rolled out higher prices in the summer of 2014. Prices also were increased in June 2013.
Starbucks' customers are nonchalant about price increases. Market research has shown that most Starbucks customers, stopped after leaving the store, don't know what they paid for the coffee.
How strong is the Starbucks brand? Research by online real estate lister Zillow.com found that when a Starbucks moves into a neighborhood, home prices rise at double the standard rate.
Whole Foods Market (WFM) underwent a long, deep consolidation, also beginning in November 2013. The correction was 45% deep, which isn't ideal.

The trend toward healthy eating may have seemed like a passing fad a few years ago, but it appears to be here to stay. That's good news for a company like Whole Foods Market (WFM), which helped pioneer the trend, and even traditional grocers like Kroger (KR).
IBD's supermarket industry group ranked No. 3 out of 197 groups in Thursday's edition.
Grocers like Kroger have been upgrading their offerings with natural and organic foods to meet competition from Whole Foods and others.
In response, Whole Foods has been forced to lower prices.
This worried investors, but now some analysts say the lower prices have been more than offset by attracting more customers.

In its fiscal Q1 report issued Feb. 11, Whole Foods said earnings rose 10% from a year ago. That follows earnings that were flat, up 8% and up 9% the previous three quarters, showing acceleration in earnings. Sales rose 10%. Analysts forecast an 11% EPS increase in the next report.
The stock was hammered last May, but has since stabilized and is rising, forming a long, deep base.
It needs more work to be in a position to safely buy.
Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) came public in August 2013.
After a brief rise, the stock fell into a prolonged correction.
But, like Whole Foods, it seems to be building a long, deep base. It found support Thursday at its 50-day moving average.
Despite the stock's action, earnings growth has continued unabated. Late Wednesday, the company reported EPS that rose 71%, well above analysts' estimates, while sales increased 21%.
The company lost money in 2011, but since then has a three-year annualized EPS growth rate of 292%.
Earnings in the next report are forecast to rise 22%.
Over the past decade, Kroger has been upgrading its stores to meet shoppers' expectations and improve the shopping experience.
Analysts say its move into more natural food have been a major reason earnings have been growing.
It's paid off for investors. The stock price has risen from the mid-20s in 2012 to over 70 today. The stock has been up 12 of the past 13 months.
In the most recent quarterly report, earnings grew at a 30% clip, the best growth in six quarters. Sales rose 11%. In the next report, analysts see a 15% EPS increase.
Kroger owns grocery and convenience stores and jewelry and department stores under the Ralphs, Kwik Shop, Fred Meyer, Food 4 Less, Dillons and City Market names.
Fresh Market (TFM) is another player in the healthy food space. It offers small-format stores that seek to evoke the European-style market with a rustic atmosphere, emphasizing fresh ingredients.

In the most recent report, EPS grew 17% from a year ago. Analysts forecast 13% growth this year and 14% next year.The trend toward healthy eating may have seemed like a passing fad a few years ago, but it appears to be here to stay. Upscale grocer Whole Foods Market (WFM) is expected to report slowing earnings and revenue growth after the close Wednesday, but one analyst sees potential to grab market share in the online grocery delivery space.Wall Street anticipates earnings rising about 10% to 45 cents a share, which would mark a slowdown from 16% growth last quarter. Revenue is seen growing 9% to $3.69 billion vs. 10% growth in Q2.Oppenheimer analyst Rupesh Parikh expects same-store sales to miss consensus views, which could weigh on the grocer's stock."Based on our work, we believe comps could come in around 2.5%, slightly below a 2.9% Street figure," said Parikh in a Monday note. "Historically comp shortfalls have represented negative catalysts for shares."Shares have been falling since July 17, edging down 0.9% to 40.07 in the stock market today. The stock has been trading below its 50-day line since breaking support last week.Parikh cut his price target to 48 from 50 "to reflect increased risks with the company's new strategy, as well as what appears to be a step up in the competitive environment for natural/organic lately."As more stores widen their selection of natural and organic fare, Whole Foods has faced pressure from traditional grocers like Kroger (KR) and big-box retailers such asTarget (TGT).Part of the company's "new strategy" also includes an attempt to draw the millennial market. In June, it unveiled 365 by Whole Foods Market, a "streamlined, value-focused brand" that will open shop next year.The millennial-focused concept didn't sit well with some analysts. Cowen and Co. analyst Jerry Gray reduced his price target on the company to 46 from 53 on July 13 on the "increased risk" the new chain poses."Although our proprietary survey data suggests the market opportunity for 365 is massive, we see elevated risk to sales and margin due to competition with the core Whole Foods brand and online search data points to slowing mind share among consumers," Gray wrote.But delivery — a feature more companies are rolling out — could be a sweet spot for the company.Gray wrote Monday that Whole Foods, which has a partnership with grocery delivery service Instacart, is "best positioned to gain share" in the online grocery delivery market. Instacart also offers delivery from membership warehouse store Costco (COST).Panera Bread (PNRA), Starbucks and Whole Foods Market "are best positioned to benefit as these brands have favorable perceptions among higher income and urban demographics and have demonstrated the most willingness to grow the delivery channel," he said.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) has also recently introduced its own delivery options.Last month, Whole Foods came under fire for allegedly overcharging New York City shoppers, though it has denied doing so. New York City authorities have begun an investigation.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.RELATED:Albertsons Files For IPO Amid Industry ConsolidationWhole Foods Or 'Whole Paycheck?' Price Check In NYCWhole Foods Curious? New Concept's Name Says It All.

Albertsons said in a regulatory filing Wednesday that it plans to raise up to $100 million in an initial public offering, nine years after going private.
The second-largest grocery store chain in the U.S. is privately owned by an investor group that includes Cerberus Capital Management and operates Jewel-Osco, Acme and Tom Thumb supermarkets.
Albertsons said it planned to use the money raised to pay down debt and other corporate purposes. It also has plans to open new stores and is looking at potential acquisitions.

Earlier this year, it bought rival Safeway, sparking consolidation in the industry. In June, Europe's Ahold said it would buy Delhaize in a deal valued at $10.4 billion. Delhaize operates the Food Lion and Hannaford chains in the eastern U.S. while Ahold operates the Stop & Shop and Giant supermarkets as well as the Peapod online grocery delivery service.
In its Q1 conference call, Kroger's (KR) CEO said he continues to see consolidation in the industry and expects the chain to be in on the action.

Competition in the low-margin grocery industry is getting more intense. Wal-Mart (WMT) has invested in smaller format stores in urban centers. Whole Foods (WFM) recently launched a new concept aimed at 20- to 30-somethings.
Competition has shifted to online as well. Amazon (AMZN), Google (GOOGL) and Wal-Mart are growing their online delivery operations.

European grocers Ahold and Delhaize said Wednesday they would merge, strengthening their position in the U.S. as continued consolidation is seen in the U.S. grocery store space. Ahold said it will buy Delhaize in an all-stock deal valued at $10.4 billion, with the combined company, to be called Ahold Delhaize, worth about $29.5 billion, making it the largest public European…

Kroger's (KR) price competitiveness against Whole Foods Market (WFM) and Wal-Mart (WMT), two peers on the opposite ends of the grocery store spectrum, is seen as an advantage that Wall Street expects to support growth for the top and bottom lines.

When Kroger issues fiscal first-quarter results Thursday morning, its earnings are projected to increase 11% to $1.21 a share, while revenue is estimated to rise 1.2% to $33.35 billion. Those figures represent a slowdown from Q4's 33% earnings growth and 9% sales growth.

But price checks conducted this spring in Denver showed that Kroger is "very competitively priced" against Whole Foods Market and Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM), according to Deutsche Bank's Karen Short in a March 19 research report.

"These results reaffirm our view that Kroger's price/value position remains very strong, so Kroger's many competitive advantages should support sustainable growth," Short said. "Specifically, Kroger can react to pockets of intrusion by category (natural-organic) or by geography and the impact to Kroger's earnings power is almost undetectable."
Short also noted that Kroger's ability to be price-competitive comes from its large-scale, strong market-share positions, extensive private-brand portfolio and a big customer-loyalty program.
The analyst reiterated a buy rating on Kroger shares and raised her price target to 90 from 80.
Wolfe Research's Scott Mushkin said Kroger "continues to turn the screws" on its promotional-pricing strategy, which is driving sales and customer loyalty.
Kroger reduced its premium to Wal-Mart to less than 10%, from nearly 20% in the summer of 2014, he said in a March 19 research report.
Kroger shares are working on a flat base with a 77.84 buy point. Kroger is currently trading about 8% below that level and has been hitting resistance at its 50-day line.

Kroger leads the Retail-Super/Mini Markets industry group with an IBD Composite rating of 86 out of 99, meaning its shares outperform 86% of all stocks in the market as measured by fundamental and technical factors. Some of those factors are earnings and sales growth, profit margins, return on equity and relative price performance.

The sales numbers from big U.S. retailers over the holidays were deflating — with the notable exception of e-commerce leader Amazon.com (AMZN), which had its best holiday season ever.But the pressure Amazon has applied to Wal-Mart (WMT), Kroger (KR), Target (TGT) and other retailers is about to get more intense with Amazon's expansion into its opponents' lair: brick-and-mortar retail.Amazon is set to open its first Amazon Go convenience store, an actual physical store. Other Go stores will soon follow.Amazon Go, announced in early December, is a small (1,800-square-foot) convenience store with a novel twist — there are no check-out lines. In-store wireless technology will tabulate your purchases and charge your Amazon account.Physical-store retailing may never be the same, some observers say."The most impressive thing they are doing is tying together the best retail technology into one operation that should effectively reinvent the basic retail model as we know it," said Bill Bishop, co-founder and managing partner of Brick Meets Click, a consulting and retail advisory services company. "What Amazon is doing will radically increase the efficiency and productivity of the retail model."IBD'S TAKE: Amazon is gaining ground in large retail markets beyond its core markets of electronics and media, putting the e-commerce giant in position for a strong performance in 2017.The Amazon Go stores will sell a range of groceries, specialty foods and ready-to-eat meals. The first Amazon Go, near Amazon headquarters in Seattle, is being tested by Amazon employees ahead of the official opening, which the company says will be early this year.Amazon says its checkout-free shopping experience "is made possible by the same types of technologies used in self-driving cars: computer vision, sensor fusion, and deep learning." The technology automatically detects when products are taken from or returned to the shelves and keeps track.Amazon hasn't said how many Amazon Go stores it plans to open, but its usual intent is to make every market it enters a multibillion-dollar business. The company does now have three physical bookstores (in Seattle, Portland and San Diego) that are more or less conventional stores, though customers can download books they find in the stores to their Kindle or other devices. Five more bookstores are in the works, in New York City, Chicago, New Jersey and two Boston suburbs.The stand-alone grocery store, however, marks a new phase in Amazon's ambitions to rule at least parts of the conventional brick-and-mortar store world. Besides Go, Amazon reportedly is exploring other formats for food stores and curbside pickup facilities.Amazon stock, trading near record highs touched in October, rose 0.74% to 827.46 in the stock market today. The stock has formed a cup-with-handle base, with a buy point of 843.94.Wal-Mart is paying attention. The No. 1 retailer intends to bring online ordering of groceries and curbside pickup service to nearly a quarter of its roughly 4,600 U.S. stores by year-end, Wal-Mart executives recently said. Wal-Mart also has reorganized its e-commerce unit and assigned new executive positions.And in September, it bought rising e-commerce startup Jet.com for $3.3 billion. Jet.com founder Marc Lore is now CEO of Wal-Mart's e-commerce operation.Meanwhile, Amazon continues to experiment in the grocery business aside from the Go stores. It offers a same-day and next-day grocery delivery service, through Amazon Fresh, in several big cities. But delivering groceries that customers order online has been a failed business model for about 15 years — first tried then abandoned by companies such as Webvan during the go-go dot-com bubble period around 2000.Bishop says Amazon, too, might be such a casualty — unable to attract the high volume of customers needed to make grocery deliveries a profitable business,"I think they hit a bit of a wall in terms of growth and penetration," Bishop said. "I believe that Amazon Fresh has not met their expectations, and that the Amazon Go store is a response" to that failure, as Amazon tries "to figure out how to get more people buying their groceries."Amazon is attacking the grocery market from the angles of a hybrid model that includes online shopping, a grocery pickup service and in-store no-checkout shopping, approaches "we believe will accelerate Amazon's penetration in the grocery business," Bishop said.Amazon is deep in a test-and-learn stage with groceries and Amazon Go, says Meaghan Werle, an analyst at broad-based retail consulting firm Kantar Retail"We expect a slow and pretty disciplined rollout of this store concept as Amazon tries to figure out how to sell groceries and tackle the brick-and-mortar space," Werle said.Amazon Go extends Amazon's foray into the physical world that started with the bookstores — the first one opened in Seattle in November 2015 — where besides books Amazon also features its consumer electronics products, the Kindle e-readers, Echo and Echo Dot home smart speakers, Fire tablet and Fire TV stick.Amazon also reportedly plans to open dozens of small pop-up retail kiosk-type storefronts  in shopping malls over the next year to showcase its hardware devices."Amazon has acknowledged that there is value in brick and mortar," Werle said.There is a lot of value, in fact. Annual U.S. grocery and beverage sales alone approach $800 billion,"Consumables are such a huge interest to Amazon," said Werle. "And in order to expand their grocery presence they need to establish more brick-and-mortar stores."The small-store concept in groceries, however, already has been tried and abandoned by retailers such as Wal-Mart.In 2011, Wal-Mart began experimenting with a small-store concept called Express, which included low-cost goods and groceries. Wal-Mart eventually closed all 269 stores.Werle says Amazon has a better shot at success thanks to its efficiencies in its supply-chain delivery process and other technologies that fit better with small-store economics.A report from Cowen last March said Amazon already controls an estimated 1.1% of the $795 billion U.S. food and beverage business through various Prime offerings, including Pantry and its fresh-grocery delivery service, Fresh. Wal-Mart, including Sam's Club, leads with 21%, according to Cowen analysts John Blackledge. Kroger is No. 2 with a 9% share, followed by Albertson's/Safeway, Costco (COST) and Publix.In December, Amazon announced it would expand its full-time U.S.-based workforce by 100,000, to a total of 280,000, by mid-2018. The company said the added employees are needed in large part to staff the expansion of their order-fulfillment centers.But Pacific Crest Securities says the new hires also could be part of Amazon's push to accelerate efforts to build physical stores."Amazon will also add nonfulfillment center jobs, but we think that still leaves a significant and unexplained gap," wrote Pacific Crest analyst Edward Yruma. "We believe that this could be explained by an accelerated rollout of physical stores."In particular, he wrote, "We think that a potential grocery pickup concept looks particularly promising."RELATED:Amazon: Still The E-Commerce Elephant In The Retail Room?After The Mall Doors Close, Analysts Cut Macy's, Kohl; Chipotle UpgradedRetailers Face 2017 'Reckoning,' More 'Sad Malls' As Amazon Keeps BoomingNordstorm's '1972' Warning Is Another Sign Of Dying Malls

Whole Foods Market (WFM) and cybersecurity firm Qualys (QLYS) reported earnings after the closing bell, with both reporting lighter-than-expected sales and guidance.Estimates: Whole Foods Market is expected to report a 14% EPS decline to 39 cents, which would be its third straight year-over-year decline. Fiscal Q1 sales should climb 3% to $4.979 billion.Results: Q1 EPS of 39 cents excluding a variety of items. Sales edged up nearly 2% to $4.9 billion. Same-store sales fell 2.4%, their sixth straight decline.Outlook: Whole Foods sees fiscal 2017 EPS of $1.33 or greater, with sales growth of 1.5% or more. Analysts had expected EPS of $1.44 and stronger sales gains. The grocer now sees same-store sales down as much as 2.5% this fiscal year, with comps in the current quarter down 3.2% so far.Whole Foods plans to close nine locations in the current quarter, something it hasn't done since 2008, during the severe recession. It will still open six locationsStock: Shares fell more than 6% in early after-hours action, but pared losses to about 2%. Whole Foods closed up 1.1% to 29.30 on the stock market today.Whole Foods Market stock has been in a long-term decline. The organic and natural foods grocer pioneer has struggled with high prices as competitors proliferate, including pure-play Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) and mainline grocer Kroger (KR).Estimates: Qualys is expected to report a 14% EPS decline to 18 cents, with sales up 18% to $52.62 million.Results: Qualys earned 23 cents, with sales of $52.2 million.Outlook: Qualys sees Q1 EPS of 17-19 cents with sales of $52 million to $53 million. Analysts expected EPS of 21 cents and sales of $54.48 million. For the full-year, Qualys predicts EPS of 81-86 cents and revenue of $224 million to $228 million. Wall Street had been looking for EPS of 91 cents and revenue of $233.51 million.Stock: Shares fell nearly 8% in late trade. The stock had closed up 0.3% to 36.85 after rising intraday above a 37.10 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. Shares peaked above that entry on Feb. 3, but pulled back on Monday.Cybersecurity stocks were hot for much of 2016, but have slumped. Fortinet (FTNT), Check Point Software (CHKP) and Symantec (SYMC) reported strong results in recent weeks, but FireEye (FEYE) plunged on its quarterly figures.RELATED:Do Fortinet, Check Point Earnings Mean Upside For Palo Alto, Cisco?MaxLinear Beats Q4 Targets, But Sales Guidance Lags, Stock Falls

Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) and Rite Aid (RAD) should win regulatory approval soon, the New York Post reported Wednesday, sending shares of both drugstore chains higher.The Federal Trade Commission is trying to get the $9-a-share deal, first announced back in October 2015, OK'd before Donald Trump takes office on Jan. 20, the New York Post said, citing a source. Trump is expected to ask FTC Chairwoman Edith Ramirez to step down, leaving the FTC with just two commissioners on a five-person board.The FTC deal will include Rite Aid's planned sale of 865 stores to Fred's (FRED) to satisfy antitrust concerns. That action will more than double Fred's footprint.Walgreens Boots Alliance climbed 2.1% to close at 84.43 on the stock market today after rising intraday to 85.26. Rite Aid jumped 3.4% to 8.60. Fred's initially rose but reversed to trade down 5% to 16.93.Kroger (KR) at one point had been in the running to buy some Rite Aid locations, but reportedly had wanted to close many of those sites and make them in-grocery locations. The FTC wanted stand-alone stores. Kroger shares dipped 0.4% to close at 33.07.IBD'S TAKE: Telecom companies could make a flurry of takeover deals during the Trump administration. In 2017, telecom M&A scenarios trump earnings outlooks.Separately, Walgreens and FedEx (FDX) announced a deal to offer FedEx pickup and drop-off at Walgreens locations. The service will begin at a few stores in the spring, but the plan is to expand to nearly 8,000 locations by the fall of 2018. The deal would expand FedEx delivery options and give e-commerce shoppers a reason to come into Walgreens.FedEx shares fell 0.4% to 189.24.

Walgreens Boots Alliance's (WBA) first-quarter profit topped Wall Street estimates Thursday, and the drugstore chain raised the low end of its full-year outlook.Earnings per share rose 6.8% to $1.10, beating views by a penny. But revenue fell 1.8% to $28.5 billion, falling short of views for $29.2 billion.Walgreens raised the low end of its full-year EPS outlook by five cents to a range of $4.90-$5.20, with the midpoint above the consensus for $5.01.Walgreens shares fell intraday but rallied to close up 0.1% at 83.03 on the stock market today.The company also said it was working to close its pending $17.2 billion acquisition of Rite Aid (RAD) in the early part of the year.Rite Aid shares fell 1% to 8.19.IBD'S TAKE: Drug stock investors, relieved that Hillary Clinton won't be president, now worry that Donald Trump will impose drug price controls.In December, Rite Aid agreed to sell 865 stores to Fred's (FRED) for $950 million in cash to help ease antitrust concerns ahead of its merger with Walgreens. But that sale is contingent on the Walgreens-Rite Aid deal going through.Kroger (KR) had been considering buying hundreds of Rite Aid and Walgreens stores and converting them into in-grocery store locations. But reportedly the FTC wants them to stay stand-alone drugstores.Fred's shares sank 4.4%. Kroger shares dipped 0.1%.RELATED: Fred's Adopts Poison Pill After Hedge Fund Wants In On Rite Aid Talks

Rite Aid (RAD) on Tuesday agreed to sell 865 stores to Fred's (FRED) for $950 million in cash to help ease antitrust concerns ahead of its merger with Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA).The sale could mean the pharmacies are closer to getting their $17.2 billion merger OK'd by the Federal Trade Commission. In October Walgreens extended the merger deadline to 2017 to gain regulatory approval.But it also means that Fred's would more than double its footprint and expand its geographical reach with the acquisition.Fred's shares jumped 81% to 20.19 in the stock market today.Rite Aid shares rose 5.4% to 8.61, hitting their highest level since October 2015, when the Walgreens deal was first announced. Walgreens shares edged up 0.3% to 86.28.Investors and analysts have been skeptical that the FTC will approve the Walgreens-Rite Aid merger, which would combine the No. 1 and No. 2 drugstore changes. The Rite Aid sale to Fred's would follow FTC approval, if it comes.IBD'S TAKE: Drug stock investors, relieved that Hillary Clinton won't be president, now worry that Donald Trump will impose drug price controls.Kroger (KR) has been considering buying hundreds of Rite Aid and Walgreens stores and perhaps moving them into in-grocery store locations. But reportedly the FTC wants them to stay stand-alone drugstores.In September Walgreens said it is "exploring potential divestiture remedies" to sell 500-1,000 stores to help get regulatory approval.Kroger shares dipped 1.1%.Rite Aid will announce quarterly earnings Thursday.RELATED: Kroger Cautious On 2016, 2017 Earnings As Food Price Deflation ContinuesPraxair, Linde Agree On Tentative 'Merger Of Equals'

Nvidia (NVDA) and KLA-Tencor (KLAC) were upgraded to buys, coverage was initiated on Amgen (AMGN) with an outperform rating, and Kroger (KR) was upgraded to neutral while Qualcomm (QCOM) was downgraded to neutral in analyst notes released Wednesday.Graphics chipmaker Nvidia was upgraded to a buy with a price target of 120 by Evercore ISI. Nvidia stock jumped on Nov. 11 after crushing Wall Street estimates for its fiscal third-quarter sales and earnings estimates and guiding higher for the current quarter. Nvidia's core gaming business, which accounts for 62% of sales, grew 63% year over year to $1.2 billion in revenue. The stock is up 175% this year.Nvidia stock jumped 5.8% to a record closing high of 96.45 on the stock market today. Nvidia has been consolidating, following a post-earnings spike, since Nov. 17, with an all-time high of 96.62 set on Dec. 8.Qualcomm was downgraded to neutral from overweight by JPMorgan with a price target of 70. The research note said challenges facing the company include consumer weakness outside the U.S. and slowing smartphone demand in China.Qualcomm stock fell 2.6% to finish at 67.56 after rising 1.3% on Tuesday.IBD'S TAKE: Qualcomm is among several top chip stocks that have entered or neared buy range this week.Coverage was initiated on Amgen by Oppenheimer with an outperform rating and price target of 166, saying Amgen is nearing a key inflection point. It said Amgen currently has thirteen major products on the market."We would characterize six of these products as mature and seven as growth products. We anticipate the introduction of two new compounds, currently in late-stage clinical development, plus three biosimilars," the report said.Amgen stock rose 0.2% to 148.69.Kroger was upgraded to neutral from underweight by Piper Jaffray with a price target of 34. The grocery heavyweight on Dec. 1 cut the high end of its 2016 earnings views and guided 2017 profit growth lower.Kroger stock climbed 0.9% to 34.72.KLA-Tencor was upgraded to strong buy from buy at Needham with a price target of $95. Demand is growing for process control equipment, Needham said. The chip gear maker topped earnings views on Oct. 20.KLA-Tencor ended down 0.2% at 77.81.
