Stocks seesawed to a lower finish on Veterans Day Wednesday. The Dow Jones industrial average, the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 all ended down 0.3%. According to preliminary data, volume was lower across the board in the stock market today.After the close, shares of Popeyes Louisiana Kitchen (PLKI) jumped more than 5% after the company posted Q3 results that beat views. The fried chicken chain reported earnings of 47 cents a share on sales of $61.1 million. Views were for 45 cents a share on revenue of $61.9 million. It also slightly raised its full-year profit outlook to a range of $1.86 to $1.91 a share, vs. views of $1.90.In the regular session, Horizon Pharma (HZNP) gapped down and plunged nearly 20% after pharmacy benefits manager Express Scripts (ESRX) filed a lawsuit against the company for $140 million over a contract dispute.AmTrust Financial Services (AFSI) gapped below its 50-day line and slumped 8% after pricing a secondary offering of 5 million shares. The insurance firm said that it would take in $315 million before expenses. Intraday, it fell more than 8% below a 69.84 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.Despite a rather lackluster session, TAL Education (XRS) rallied 3% and scored a new high in fast trade. It followed through Wednesday after clearing a 38.75 buy point from a late-stage cup-with-handle Tuesday. The company provides tutoring in China.Luxoft (LXFT) gapped up and jumped 7% after beating views and raising guidance. Late Tuesday, the company reported adjusted fiscal Q2 earnings of 84 cents a share, up 45% from a year earlier. Profit growth has now accelerated for two quarters. Sales rose 29% to $161.5 million. Luxoft lifted its full-year profit outlook by a nickel to $2.60 a share. The stock is now extended 9% past a 68.95 buy point from a flat base.Weekly jobless claims will be out Thursday morning. A host of central bank officials will be speaking throughout the day, including Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen, St. Louis Fed chief James Bullard and Richmond Fed President Jeffrey Lacker.Advance Auto Parts (AAP) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) are a couple of notable companies reporting earnings Thursday.Follow Vincent Mao on Twitter @IBD_VMao.

The stock market put in a solid day as the Nasdaq vaulted to an all-time high, finishing at 5132.95, a hair's breadth above the 5132.52 intraday high set at the end of the dot-com bubble on March 10, 2000.Volume was higher on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq exchanges, according to preliminary data.The Nasdaq rose 1.3%, and the S&P; 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 1% in the stock market today.Wearable device maker Fitbit (FIT) held early gains and closed 48% above its offering price of 20 a share in its NYSE debut.Grocer Kroger (KR) jumped in the morning on an upbeat earnings report, but gave up most of its gain by the end of the day, closing up less than 1%.Palo Alto Networks (PANW) rose more than 1% to a new high. RBC Capital Markets raised its price target to 200 from 180. Analyst Matthew Hedberg said companies are in the early stages of spending on security software.Before the market opens Friday, CarMax (KMX) is expected to report EPS of 86 cents, 13% above the year-ago number. KB Home (KBH) is expected to announce earnings of 8 cents a share, down from 70 cents a year ago.

Stock futures blipped higher ahead of Thursday's open, as the market appeared set to build on Wednesday's late-day rally. Dow futures traded 107.6 points above fair market value, but had come well off earlier highs. Nasdaq 100 futures were up a strong 33.8 points. S&P 500 futures showed a 12.9-point gain.

The stock market today heads into the session with the Nasdaq down 1.6% and the S&P 500 2% lower this week. The IBD 50 Index is down 2%. The Russell 2000 opens with a 1.5% loss. A rally late in Wednesday's session, following the release of the Federal Reserve' September beige book report, left both the Nasdaq and S&P 500 at the top of their day's trading ranges — a positive sign. But little has changed with regard to the overall messages the correcting market is sending: Be patient, build watch lists, watch for a follow-through day.

Investor attention is on the August nonfarm payroll report due out Friday. But Thursday's preliminaries included the August Job Cuts report from Challenger Gray & Christmas. It showed the number of layoffs slowing sharply vs. July's four-year high, but up 2.9% compared with year-ago figures as employers announced plans to cut 41,186 workers. The retail sector accounted for nearly 25% of those layoffs, most tied to the bankruptcy of grocery chain A&P, the report said.
Initial jobless claims rose 4.4% to 282,000 in the week ended Aug. 29, the Labor Department said. Economist consensus had projected 272,000 claims. The four-week moving average edged up to 275,500.
In stocks, Grifols (GRFS) rose 4%, SunEdison (SUNE) jumped 3%, but the market continued to be hard on any slip-ups in late season earnings reports.

Five Below (FIVE) was 10% below this morning after weak Q2 revenue and Q3 guidance upended its quarterly results. Verint Systems (VRNT) tumbled 7% as better-than-expected Q2 earnings and revenue did not offset full-year earnings guidance below consensus views.

Generic drug maker Lannett (LCI) spiked 17% in premarket trade. The Philadelphia-based company said it would pay $1.23 billion to acquire Kremers Urban Pharmaceuticals, the U.S. generic drug unit of Belgium-based UCB. Kremers, which owns a portfolio of 18 drugs and a strong pipeline of pending applications and candidates, will effectively double Lannett's revenue. Lannett ended Wednesday 32% below an April high after falling below its 40-week line of support in early August.

Switzerland-based Syngenta (SYT) rolled up a 3% gain after announcing it would seek to divest its vegetable seed business and launch a $2 billion share repurchase program. Syngenta sees more than 50% of its revenue from herbicides and insecticides. The stock ended Wednesday 31% below a June high.

Leading stocks were unusually flat ahead of the open. Refinery operator Tesoro (TSO) posted the largest move among IBD 50 stocks, down 3% in premarket trade. The stock has been working to fashion a bottom to its three-week consolidation, hovering between its 10- and 40-week moving averages.

Overseas, China's markets were closed as the country celebrated the anniversary of the end of WWII. Europe's markets laid in healthy gains, with leading indexes up more than 1% across the board near midday.

The dollar traded flat vs. the euro, down against the yen. Bonds slipped, but not much. Crude oil eased a few pennies, with West Texas Intermediate holding above $46 a barrel and up about 2% this week. Syngenta sees more than 50% of its revenue from herbicides and insecticides. The stock ended Wednesday 31% below a June high.Leading stocks were unusually flat ahead of the open. Refinery operator Tesoro (TSO) posted the largest move among IBD 50 stocks, down 3% in premarket trade. The stock has been working to fashion a bottom to its three-week consolidation, hovering between its 10- and 40-week moving averages.Overseas, China's markets were closed as the country celebrated the anniversary of the end of WWII. Europe's markets laid in healthy gains, with leading indexes up more than 1% across the board near midday.The dollar traded flat vs. the euro, down against the yen. Bonds slipped, but not much. Crude oil eased a few pennies, with West Texas Intermediate holding above $46 a barrel and up about 2% this week. Gold eased to $1,167 an ounce, down less than 1% for the week.

The name is an extension of Whole Foods' house brand, 365 Everyday Value. The stores, scheduled to open next year, will carry both 365 products and national brands,…

Walmart (WMT) subsidiary Sam's Club has teamed up with Instacart to provide same-day delivery of groceries as the retail giant steps up its battle with online shopping titan Amazon (AMZN).Sam's Club is Walmart's warehouse rival to Costco Wholesale (COST).Walmart also announced Tuesday it is launching four private-label apparel brands as it beefs up its clothing offerings both online and at its brick and mortar stores. It will also launch its first ever digital-only brand, a line of bedding that will be available on a separate website.The Dow Jones Industrial Average component fell 1.7% to 91.2 on the stock market today. Last week the retail giant's stock tumbled more than 11% after Walmart missed fourth-quarter profit estimates and reported a sharp slowdown in U.S. e-commerce sales growth.Sign Up For Free IBD Newsletters: Market Prep | Tech ReportWhile Amazon is the dominant market leader in grocery delivery, Instacart is the most popular alternative for supermarket orders in the U.S. Instacart still delivers groceries for Whole Foods Market, acquired by Amazon last year.Costco and grocery giant Kroger (KR) also use Instacart.Goods that will be available under the new Sam's Club-Instacart service, initially covering Austin, Texas, Dallas-Fort Worth, and St. Louis, will include produce, meat, and frozen foods to everyday essentials and small appliances.Instacart customers will be able to shop without a Sam's Club membership, giving them access to cheaper prices and bulk shopping options, paired with the convenience of same-day delivery. Sam's Club members will be able to input their membership number to receive membership rewards and lower, member-only pricing on items."We know our members love our mix of exciting items, and appreciate it when we make life a little easier for them. Whether it's Scan & Go, Club Pickup — and now delivery in as little as an hour — shopping with Sam's Club is getting easier and more convenient, and we're just getting started," Sam's Club's VP of omnichannel and in-club product Padwal Sachin said in a press release.In addition to the Sam's Club announcement, Walmart is also launching four clothing brands, including Time and Tru for women, plus size women's brand Terra & Sky and Wonder Nation for kids. George for men will also be getting a refresh. The latter is a popular brand at the firm's Asda stores in the U.K., where it is marketed as quality fashion clothing at affordable prices.The new brands will be available in online and in stores starting March 1.Walmart will also be jazzing up its clothing departments, with signs and fitting group upgrades coming to select storesIt is also launching the Allswell line of mattresses and bedding, which will be Walmart's first digital brand. It will be sold through AllswellHome.com rather than in stores.The S&P 500 component has acquired small online brands including Shoebuy, Modcloth and Bonobos over the past 12 months as it works to boost growth in its clothing and accessories business, a popular space among online consumers. It is also dedicating space to department store Lord & Taylor on the Walmart website, a tie-up which comes into force this spring.The moves come as analysts question whether Walmart can compete with online retail giant Amazon.IBD'S TAKE: With thousands of publicly traded companies to choose from, how can you quickly find the best stocks to buy right now? A good starting point is to regularly review screens that highlight the top-rated equities."Compared to Amazon's 24% growth in the fourth quarter for online stores and third-party seller services off a dramatically larger base, it is becoming increasingly clear that Amazon's lead over the traditional retailer is only growing," Evercore analyst Anthony DiClemente said in a research note."This lead is likely to take on greater importance as billions of e-commerce dollars come up for grabs in the coming years from greater penetration of FMCG [fast-moving consumer goods] categories," he added.Amazon shares edged down 0.7% Tuesday.However Walmart is working to close the gap, and last month it emerged the retail behemoth had trademarked the name "Wam! by Walmart," which was described in its U.S. Patent and Trademark Office filing as "retail and online grocery store services featuring home delivery service."Walmart also is currently pilot-testing fresh grocery delivery in six markets, via several couriers: Deliv in San Jose; Uber in Phoenix, Tampa, Orlando and Dallas; and in-house trucks in Denver. The pilot program is meant to provide insights into the process — presumably so Walmart can later figure out how to best scale up operations.Walmart also offers in-store pickup for online grocery orders, and is tooling around with avant-garde concepts such as "in-fridge delivery," which allows delivery drivers to ostensibly place groceries directly inside customers' refrigerators at home, using smart-home technology.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Amazon Vs. Walmart: Locking Horns In A Battle For Retail's FutureAs Walmart Gets Whacked By Amazon, This Retailer May Fashion New BreakoutAs Walmart, Amazon Expand Store Brands, Here's What Target Is Working OnRetail & E-Commerce Stocks And Industry NewsStocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth Stocks

Kroger (KR) is said to be considering a bid to acquire Overstock (OSTK), a move that would put America's largest supermarket chain squarely in the home decor business and expand its digital footprint.X The New York Post, citing a source, reported the possibility Friday. Overstock CEO Patrick Byrne told CNBC in December that he was looking to "walk away" from the e-commerce company's retail business in 60 to 90 days amid a pivot to blockchain technology. He floated, as one option, the possibility of selling the retail unit to a traditional brick-and-mortar.Kroger currently hawks home fashions and home decor through its Kroger Marketplace locations, but an Overstock deal would expand its presence. It might also give the supermarket chain some breathing room from the low-margin grocery business amid an ongoing price war with the likes of Wal-Mart (WMT), Target (TGT) and Amazon.com (AMZN).IBD'S TAKE: Everyone's getting in on the online grocery action. As Investor's Business Daily reported Thursday, Wal-Mart has trademarked "Wam! by Walmart," described as "retail and online grocery store services featuring home delivery service." The move comes as the nation's largest retailer competes with Kroger and Amazon for shopper dollars. Overstock shares spiked 9% in the stock market today. Kroger shares rose 2.3%. Amazon climbed 0.1%.Such a deal would also give Kroger a bigger footprint online, as brick-and-mortar retailers continue to seek out ways to fend off Amazon and other online shops. Amazon's $13.7 billion acquisition of Whole Foods Market last year has also put it more squarely in competition with traditional grocery stores.Kroger has reportedly been in advanced talks to acquire digital wholesaler Boxed.com, dubbed "Costco for millennials," a company that the Post says has also gotten investment interest from General Mills (GIS) and Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY). The startup would bolster either company's distribution network.Costco Wholesale shares inched up 0.4%.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:Amazon Raises Monthly Fee On Prime Membership Program 18%Here's Why Wal-Mart Is 'Still Very Much In Control Of Its Own Destiny'Here Are Your 20 Cities Vying For Amazon's New Headquarters

To get ready for earnings season, focus on stocks in or near a potential buy zone ahead of their next quarterly report. One such company is IBD 50 member Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM). It's expected to release its latest numbers around Feb. 22. The stock is approximately 4% above a 26.08 buy point from a first-stage consolidation.X Keep in mind that buying just before a stock reports can be risky, since an EPS or sales miss could send it sharply lower. You can minimize your risk by waiting to see how the company reports and how the market reacts. You can also use an options strategy to limit your potential downside.Looking For Winning Stocks? Try This Simple RoutineTaking a look at revenue and profit performance, the company has posted three quarters of accelerating earnings growth. Revenue growth has also increased during the same period. Analysts are looking for EPS growth of 25% for the quarter, and 20% growth for the full year. Annual EPS estimates were recently revised upward. The company has a 97 Composite Rating and holds the No. 1 rank among its peers in the Retail-Super/Mini Markets industry group. Ingles Markets (IMKTA) and Kroger (KR) are also among the group's highest-rated stocks.Note: Dates for earnings reports are subject to change. Check the company's website for any updates. Concerns that Whole Foods Market (WFM) has too many rivals in upscale groceries are overblown and have gone "stale," Sterne Agee said Wednesday in upgrading the stock to buy from neutral.Sterne Agee analysts said in an upgrade note that while there was little to drive same-store sales growth in 2013, Whole Foods has emerged from 2014 as a "stronger and more focused" company that was "back on the offensive." Sterne Agee also raised its price target on the stock to 60.The investment firm also raised its first-quarter earnings-per-share expectations by a penny to 46 cents, which is also a penny above analyst consensus. Sterne Agee also hiked its EPS outlook by 7 cents to $1.77, above views for $1.72.Shares rose 3.4% to 53.08 on the news in the stock market today. Earlier, they peaked at 53.29, their highest point since March.The high-end grocery chain, which has helped steer consumer tastes toward healthier, purportedly higher-quality food, has faced competition from the likes of Kroger (KR) and Costco (COST), which have tried to appeal to more refined tastes without the steeper costs.But Sterne Agee cited a variety of recent developments at Whole Foods to justify their upgrade that may encourage shoppers to keep paying a bit more: the growth of home-delivery plans via Instacart; stronger marketing efforts; the incorporation of Apple Pay in all of its locations; a produce rating system and events such as its "Wine Club" delivery service.As the economy continues to rebound, wealthier shoppers, who were more protected from the downturn to begin with, will continue to help drive Whole Foods' same-store sales to the upper end of the company's 2015 forecasts of gains in the "low to mid-single digits", Sterne Agee said. Sterne Agee also said that the company has directed more effort toward reducing employment costs, via a more effective combination of part-time and full-time staff, and making shipping more efficient.Sterne Agee also said that those savings would free up more opportunity to cut prices. In particular, they see Whole Foods' recent moves to cut prices for produce and meats, where the price difference between Whole Foods and rivals is often the widest, drawing more customers.Since Whole Foods' most recent quarterly report in November, shares have spiked 33% and coasted well above their 50-day line. The stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 98 and has outperformed the broader market.Kroger shares rose 0.7% to 66.83. Costco fell 0.3% to 138.90.

While traditional grocers have stocked their shelves with more organic, local and higher-quality products in an attempt to draw locavores and the sustainability-conscious, the challenge that those stores pose to Whole Foods (WFM), Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) and The Fresh Market (TFM) is overstated, new research from Cowen & Co. suggests.
The research marks the latest news over the past few days to suggest that concern about those threats is waning.

On Thursday, Cowen initiated coverage on the higher-end grocery chains, giving an outperform rating to Sprouts and market perform ratings for Whole Foods and Fresh Market. The research firm also said its survey data found that traditional grocery stores' premium offerings might not be satisfying consumer demand.

"It will be challenging for conventional chains to fully meet this demand, given their need to appeal to the shopper whose top priority is price (45% of conventional shoppers, according to our survey), creating a significant opportunity for the natural grocers to continue to gain market share among the 35% of conventional shoppers that care more about product attributes and store experience than they do about absolute price," Cowen said.

Cowen said that those stores, which have largely stuck to their bets that customers will pay more for quality, could draw shoppers away from conventional grocers like Kroger (KR) and Costco (COST), and boost loyalty among the upscale markets' existing customers. Most people who shop at Whole Foods, Sprouts and Fresh Market don't consider those stores their main source for groceries, Cowen's research found.

Sprouts has the brightest prospects of the three stocks, Cowen said, largely because its produce is often around 20% cheaper than conventional grocers. Cowen forecasts 7%-8% long-term same-store sales growth. The firm's price target on Sprouts stock is 40.

Sprouts shares were down 0.5% to 35.24 in the stock market today. The stock weaved above and below its 50-day line for much of 2014 but has drifted above and away from it since last month. The company's EPS and sales have grown since its trading debut in 2013.
The initiation comes a day after Bank of America-Merrill Lynch upgraded Sprouts shares to buy from neutral and raised its price target to 42 from 35.
Cowen was less bullish on Whole Foods and Fresh Market.

While Cowen sees growth potential for Whole Foods over the next five years, analysts there said that the chain continues to suffer from a reputation for being too expensive. Cowen also said that Whole Foods' recent price cuts and slowing comp growth "have created uncertainty." Cowen's price target on Whole Foods is 53.

"Over the long term, we view this as a smart market share growth strategy, but price investments are more of an art than a science, and customer perceptions can be hard to change, which makes it difficult to predict where gross margins will trough in the intermediate term," Cowen said.
Cowen's view contrasts with that of Sterne Agee, whose upgrade note on Whole Foods, released Wednesday, said that the grocer's price cuts to produce and meat could help boost store traffic.
Whole Foods shares fell 0.3% to 52.55.

Cowen also had reservations about Fresh Market, saying that the company has had difficulty drawing regular shoppers. While Fresh Market has potential to expand its store base long-term, Cowen noted that it has sometimes struggled in ventures beyond the East Coast.
Cowen's price target on the stock is 41.

"TFM's emphasis on an elevated assortment of premium perishables is both the company's strongest differentiator and biggest challenge to generating incremental store traffic, as the majority of TFM's customers view the store as more suited to 'special' trips rather than (as) a full shop," Cowen said.

Shares rose 0.8% to 38.27.While traditional grocers have stocked their shelves with more organic, local and higher-quality products in an attempt to draw locavores and the sustainability-conscious, the challenge that those stores pose to Whole Foods (WFM), Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) and The Fresh Market (TFM) is overstated, new research from Cowen & Co. suggests.The research marks the latest news over the past few days to suggest that concern about those threats is waning.On Thursday, Cowen initiated coverage on the higher-end grocery chains, giving an outperform rating to Sprouts and market perform ratings for Whole Foods and Fresh Market. First it was a recall of nut butters on salmonella concerns. Then a fire damaged a rice factory. And if that didn't hurt Hain Celestial Group enough since last summer, weak foreign currencies provided a third kick.
On a more personal level, CEO Irwin Simon had to have knee surgery in January to repair torn ligaments from an accident.

Through it all, Hain Celestial (HAIN) has generally seen its stock climb the past few years — barring periodic gyrations, such as Feb. 9's 3% dip as the overall market fell on concerns over Greece and China.
Hain stock is up 41% from an August low, including a 5.4% jump on Feb. 4 after second-quarter earnings were reported, bringing the stock back from a January lull.

While slower than expected, net sales in Hain's December-ending second quarter of fiscal 2015 were still up 31% to an adjusted $701.7 million. Adjusted earnings rose 26% to 54 cents per share, beating views.
Whole Package
A big part of Hain's appeal is its focus on the healthy side of the packaged-goods business.

It's behind some of the biggest brands in herbal tea (Celestial Seasonings), soy milk (WestSoy), organic baby food (Earth's Best), natural soups and cereals (Health Valley), healthy snacks (Terra) and cold-pressed juices (BluePrint), to name some of the many niches the company plays in.

"Demand remains strong across all channels for natural-organic foods," said analyst Scott Van Winkle of Canaccord Genuity. "And given that Hain is a multibrand, multicategory business, it is going to participate in the growth across all channels."
CEO Simon likes to say that his company has brand offerings in 10 of the top 15 highest-penetrated organic and natural product categories. Plus, he says, it has more than 500 gluten-free products.

Van Winkle credits management for working efficiently through good and tough times. In Hain's September-ending first quarter — which included its voluntary nut-butter recall in August — Hain grew earnings and revenue more than 30% vs. the year-earlier period.

And second-quarter earnings beat views despite interrupted production from fire damage at its Tilda specialty-rice factory in the U.K. in late October, which contributed to slower than expected sales.
Hain lowered its full-year outlook to reflect the multiple headwinds, including a $70 million impact from weaker foreign currencies and $20 million from the nut butter recall and fire.
The firm expects total net sales for the year ending in June of $2.650-$2.675 billion, up 23% to 24% over the prior fiscal year. Earnings are seen rising 17%-19% to $1.85-$1.89 per share.
Analysts see revenue growing 24% to $2.671 billion and earnings going up 18% to $1.88, according to a poll by Thomson Reuters.
"The recall is behind them at this point," Van Winkle said. "But the manufacturing challenges from the fire at the Tilda facility are going to take a few quarters to work through."
Hain bought U.K.-based Basmati and specialty-rice company Tilda in January 2014. It was one of numerous acquisitions made since its founding in 1993 and the first of three in 2014.

The other two last year were Rudi's Organic Bakery and the 51.3% interest that it didn't already own in organic poultry brands FreeBird and Plainville Farms — part of its Hain Pure Protein subsidiary.
High-Profile Customers
Hain Pure Protein sells to Panera Bread (PNRA) and Chipotle (CMG), among other customers.

"Hain's ability to complete accretive and synergistic M&As (mergers and acquisitions) has been a key reason for its success in recent years," said David Palmer, an analyst with RBC Capital Markets, in a research note on Feb. 5.

As one example, Palmer noted that sales of snack-focused Sensible Portions, which Hain acquired in 2010, grew 51% for the 12-week period ending January 2. That was up from 42% growth in the prior 12-week period.
Hain competes with numerous companies. They range from small organic and natural-foods players to the big packaged-goods giants that have increasingly been adding healthier products to their mix.
General Mills (GIS), for example, acquired organic snack and convenient-meals provider Annie's Homegrown in October. Campbell Soup (CPB) bought organic baby products company Plum Organics in 2013.
"Dozens if not hundreds of companies are their competitors," Van Winkle said. "This isn't General Mills against Kellogg (K) in the cereal aisle. This is a multibrand company in a rising category."
WhiteWave Foods (WWAV), for instance, is a rival in soy milk and organic dairy milk.
Traditional supermarkets such as Safeway and Kroger (KR), mass merchants Wal-Mart (WMT) and Target (TGT), and natural-organic grocer Whole Foods (WFM) and others in its category carry Hain products.
Hain's largest single customer is United Natural Foods (UNFI), a distributor to Whole Foods and other stores. Hain's products are sold in more than 65 countries.

The U.K. is Hain's second largest market after the U.S. Second-quarter net sales in the U.K. jumped 38% vs. the year prior to $200.8 million. Tilda contributed around $50 million of the total, even with the ongoing production disruption from the fire.
U.S. net sales rose 8% to $354 million. The nut-butter recall cut into sales by $5.3 million. Rudi's added $16.1 million.
Hain saw double-digit growth in several brands, including Sensible Portions, The Greek Gods, Terra, Garden of Eatin', Imagine and WestSoy, among others.
In a Q2 conference call on Feb. 4, Simon said that business had been strong in January. He alluded to cold-weather favorites such as tea, soup and snacks.

"We love cold weather and we love snowstorms," he said.First it was a recall of nut butters on salmonella concerns. Then a fire damaged a rice factory. Hain's products are sold in more than 65 countries.The U.K. is Hain's second largest market after the U.S. Second-quarter net sales in the U.K. jumped 38% vs. the year prior to $200.8 million. Tilda contributed around $50 million of the total, even with the ongoing production disruption from the fire.U.S. net sales rose 8% to $354 million. The nut-butter recall cut into sales by $5.3 million. Rudi's added $16.1 million.Hain saw double-digit growth in several brands, including Sensible Portions, The Greek Gods, Terra, Garden of Eatin', Imagine and WestSoy, among others.In a Q2 conference call on Feb. 4, Simon said that business had been strong in January. He alluded to cold-weather favorites such as tea, soup and snacks."We love cold weather and we love snowstorms," he said.

Midcap stock mutual funds have outperformed their large- and small-cap counterparts in the past 10 years, thanks in large part to the abdication of small caps in the past year. A $10,000 investment in the average midcap stock mutual fund made on June 30, 2005, would have grown to $24,840 by Aug. 7 this year, according to Morningstar data. The…

Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) initially moved into a buy zone after delivering some pleasing preliminary earnings results. But shares reversed to close lower.X The natural foods grocery-store chain said late Monday that it expects to report per-share earnings "slightly above its previously announced guidance" of 98-99 cents, as well as a 15.3% net sales gains and 2.9% in full-year same-store sales growth.That compares to current analyst estimates for 99 cents EPS and 14.9% in sales growth for the year, according to Zacks Investment Research.Shares rose as high as 35.50 in the stock market today, crossing a 25.10 entry point from a stage-one bottoming base. But Sprouts reversed, closing down 1.5% to 24.39.In the release, Sprouts CEO Amin Maredia called the performance "a direct result of our unique model offering health and value across the store, consistent execution and focus against our strategic initiatives."For Q4, Sprouts said it sees 4.6% same-store sales growth. The announcement preceded a presentation Tuesday morning by Sprouts' CEO and CFO at the yearly ICR Conference, a key retail and restaurant-industry event.But Morningstar analyst John Brick remained cautious."We believe the announcement shows the benefits of Sprouts' differentiated model and value proposition to its customers, but we aren't wavering from our no-moat rating, as we fear the intense competitive environment will constrain profitability, as well as the firm's ability to generate excess returns on invested capital over time," he wrote.IBD's TAKE: What is a "bottoming base"? Here's how to spot one.Sprouts, Kroger (KR) and other grocer stocks faced pressure last June after Amazon first shocked the market with news that it was acquiring Whole Foods market. Then soon after the deal closed, Amazon cut prices on certain items at Whole Foods, pressuring shares of its rivals further.And now, Whole Foods products are available via Amazon, as major grocery players like Target (TGT), Wal-Mart (WMT) and Kroger work on developing their own grocery delivery capabilities.With Tuesday's move, shares of Sprouts have finally recovered above the 25 price point, a level not seen since the days before Amazon's bombshell announcement.Separately, Sprouts announced Tuesday a new partnership with Instacart, a move that will help the grocery store to expand home delivery service to major markets beyond the eight cities that Sprouts currently services.Phoenix and Tucson, Ariz. will be the first cities to benefit from the deal, with more cities to be announced at a later date, said the company."Home delivery is a natural way for Sprouts to engage with our customers on their healthy living journey, and our partnership with Instacart allows us to quickly scale for growth," said Maredia in a release on the partnership.Target said last month that it was acquiring Instacart rival Shipt, axing its relationship with Instacart.Shares of Amazon rose 0.5%, and Kroger lost 0.7%.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:Here's How Target, Amazon Are Expanding Same-Day ShippingKroger Earnings Unexpectedly Rise Despite Amazon CompetitionHere's Everything That's Changed At Whole Foods After The Amazon TakeoverRetail & E-Commerce Stocks And Industry News

What kind of person is most likely to shop at Amazon's (AMZN) new cashierless, cashless convenience-store concept, Amazon Go? The same kind of shopper who already makes frequent pit stops at BJ's Wholesale, Trader Joe's and Wal-Mart (WMT)-owned Sam's Club, according to research and consulting firm Magid.X "These three stores should be looking at what Amazon is doing as the overall concept provides the greatest opportunity, or threat, to their business," said analysts in a release.The first Amazon Go, located in Seattle, flung open its doors Monday, finally inviting everyday shoppers to peruse aisles powered by computer vision and deep-learning algorithms, and walk out the door without having to line up at a cash register. (The app automatically charges your Amazon account for whatever you take.) The store had, before that, only been open to employees as part of a beta rollout.IBD'S TAKE: Amazon isn't the only major retailer furiously developing tech-forward grocery concepts. As Investor's Business Daily previously reported, Wal-Mart recently trademarked "Wam! by Walmart," a concept that relates to "retail and online grocery store services featuring home delivery service."Target (TGT), Kroger (KR) and Costco Wholesale (COST) should also be concerned, said Magid, since more than half of Target and Kroger customers, as well as 44% of Costco shoppers, said they would consider shopping at an Amazon Go-style store.Traditional grocery stores are also at risk of losing shoppers to Amazon's concept, said the firm.Amazon hasn't indicated what its plans are for scaling up the concept, but it wouldn't be a stretch to imagine the e-commerce behemoth trying to incorporate the technology into its Whole Foods Market locations, or Whole Foods' millennial-focused "365 by Whole Foods" stores.After acquiring the upscale grocer for $13.7 billion last year, Amazon quickly began offering its smart-speaker devices at Whole Foods, and says it is working on integrating Amazon Prime into Whole Foods' point-of-sale system, intending for the online retailer's membership service to act as the grocery store's customer rewards program.Magid says Amazon Go's largest potential market consists of millennials and households with kids, with more than three in five of either category likely to shop there."The implication is clear for retailers that desire to appeal to the growing millennials subset, which is becoming more and more comfortable with an online, on-demand world: Amazon will play large in the mindset of these customers and it is imperative that they catch up," said the firm.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: FANG Stocks News & Quotes Apple (AAPL) Stock Quotes, Company News And Chart AnalysisBitcoin And Cryptocurrency News And TrendsRetail & E-Commerce Stocks And Industry News

Bitcoin's rebound paused Friday afternoon, after stabbing below the $10,000 barrier earlier this week on fears that regulators here and abroad could be looking to stamp out various forms of  cryptocurrency trading.X Bitcoin was up 1% at $11,371 after nearly retaking $12,000 earlier, according to CoinDesk. Ethereum was up 0.3% at $1,037.61.The cryptocurrencies' recovery comes after the SEC, in a letter dated Thursday, said it had asked fund sponsors to withdraw  registration statements filed for any funds with substantial investments in cryptocurrencies. The agency said there were a "number of significant investor protection issues that need to be examined before sponsors begin offering these funds to retail investors."Meanwhile, South Korea's government said it was "considering both shutting down all local virtual currency exchanges or just the ones who have been violating the law," according to a Reuters story dated Wednesday.Reuters on Tuesday also reported that a China central bank official said centralized trading of cryptocurrencies and related businesses should be banned.And the operators of the lending and exchange platform for Bitconnect, a cryptocurrency that some have alleged is a scam, said Tuesday the platform would be immediately shut down. They cited "bad press" and two cease-and-desist letters from regulators in Texas and North Carolina as among the reasons.A day later, a post on Bitconnect's website said only the lending platform would be closing and that the exchange "will work as usual" starting Thursday.The moves by regulators come amid growing warnings about cryptocurrencies' volatility, security and potential for fraud.IBD'S TAKE: Bitcoin's meteoric rise has done more than make some daredevil investors rich overnight. It's also put blockchain — the software technology enabling Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies — on a trajectory of its own.Bank of America (BAC) CEO Brian Moynihan on Wednesday said during the company's earnings call that "customers should be careful" when approaching Bitcoin.Goldman Sachs (GS) CFO Martin Chavez on Wednesday also weighed in on Bitcoin, saying that blockchain, the record-keeping technology behind Bitcoin transactions, was likely among the "important drivers of innovation" for the company.And he said the issue behind Bitcoin — how to get a bunch of people to agree on a "shared reality" — had been around for decades.He also said there were many issues to sort out before moving forward on trading financial products tied to Bitcoin."Now, the broader question of will there be trading in these instruments that are linked to Bitcoin, there is just a huge number of topics to address and being a part of the industry, we're working on all of that," he said."Custody is a part of it and it's a very complex one," he continued. "So, it's really too early to say how that will evolve for the industry or for ourselves."As for blockchain-related stocks, Riot Blockchain (RIOT) closed 0.6% higher at 19.91 on the stock market today. Overstock.com (OSTK) jumped 9% amid some buzz that grocery giant Kroger (KR) could seek to buy it.Eastman Kodak (KODK), which through a partnership introduced its own cryptocurrency and a blockchain-based image-rights-management platform this month, fell 1.5%.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN: Fierce Bitcoin Critic Now Has 'Regret'; Kodak Joins Blockchain WaveTaiwan Semiconductor Sees Strong 2018 Sales From Cryptocurrency Mining BoomBitcoin And Cryptocurrency News And Trends

One important metric to look for in a stock is an 80 or higher Relative Strength Rating. Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) just hit that mark, with a jump from 80 to 84 Wednesday. X IBD's proprietary rating measures share price movement with a 1 (worst) to 99 (best) score. The grade shows how a stock's price performance over the last 52 weeks compares to all the other stocks in our database. History reveals that the best stocks often have an 80 or higher RS Rating as they launch their biggest price moves.Looking For The Best Stocks To Buy And Watch? Start HereThe IBD 50 stock broke out earlier, but has fallen back below the prior 26.08 entry from a consolidation. If a stock you're tracking clears a buy point then retreats 7% or more below the original entry price, it's considered a failed base. Wait for the stock to set up and breakout from a new base and buy point. Also understand that the most recent consolidation is a later-stage base, and those involve more risk. Regarding fundamentals, Sprouts Farmers Market has posted three quarters of rising earnings growth. Sales growth has also increased during the same period. The company earns the No. 1 rank among its peers in the Retail-Super/Mini Markets industry group. Murphy USA (MUSA) and Kroger (KR) are also among the group's highest-rated stocks.RELATED:Stocks With Rising Relative Strength RatingsWhy Should You Use IBD's Relative Strength Rating?How Relative Strength Line Can Help You Judge A Stock

While Whole Foods Market (WFM) has been fending off rising competition from the likes of Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) and Kroger (KR) hawking natural and organic food, membership warehouse Costco (COST) might have stealthily pulled ahead in organic sales.

Costco's organic food sales are at a run rate of $4 billion, according to BMO Capital Markets analyst Kelly Bania, up from about $3 billion just six to nine months ago and "possibly now already eclipsing" industry leader Whole Foods' estimated $3.6 billion.

Costco shares fell more than 1% Friday. https://www.investors.com/stock-market-today/The stock has been building a flat base since February and has been trading below its 50-day line since breaking support at that level in mid-April.
Costco's expanding organics share could result in a slightly higher gross margin percentage and bolster its customer traffic growth outlook, says Bania, who has an outperform rating on the stock.

As the gap between the age of the average Costco member and the average American is already narrowing, Costco's growing organic presence could attract all-important younger shoppers and support "an outlook for Costco to connect with an increasingly important consumer group — millennials — where we believe Costco remains underpenetrated currently," wrote Bania.

Costco reported mixed results Wednesday as same-store sales dipped 1%, affected by currency headwinds and gas price deflation. Earnings rose 9% to $1.17, beating expectations by 2 cents, while revenue missed views for $26.63 billion with a 1% rise to $26.1 billion.
Meanwhile, Big Lots' (BIG) first-quarter earnings beat analyst estimates, but the discounter issued weak second-quarter guidance.
On Friday, Big Lots said that its Q1 EPS rose 20% to 60 cents, a penny above the 59 cents that analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected. Sales were flat at $1.28 billion.
Same-store sales were up 1.6%, in line with the 1% to 2% jump that Big Lots was expecting.

"I'm pleased with our first-quarter sales results. After a difficult start to the quarter and harsh weather conditions in February, sales trends improved in March and April," said CEO David Campisi. "Our comps for Q1 were solidly in line with our guidance and increased for a fifth consecutive quarter."
For the current quarter, Big Lots sees EPS of 31 cents to 35 cents and same-store sales increasing 2% to 3%. Analysts are expecting earnings of 37 cents per share.
Big Lots raised the low end of its full-year EPS outlook to a range of $2.80 to $2.90, up from $2.75 to $2.90. Analysts had forecast $2.87.
The stock hit a January low but still appears to be forming a base.
On Thursday, rival Dollar General (DG) named Todd Vasos as its new CEO, effective June 3.

Investors looking to buy a great stock should not only study its earnings and sales growth. Be sure to also check out a company's profit margins. Profit margins measure how much a company keeps on every dollar of sales. For example, a company that earns 22 cents for each dollar of sales before taxes has a 22% pretax profit margin.Profit margins are closely watched by Wall Street analysts and fund managers because they provide an indication of a company's fundamental strength.In some cases, a company's margins may be rising because it enjoys strong pricing power due to unique or superior products and services versus the competition.In other cases, a company may be superior at keeping costs low.Rising profit margins can justify higher stock prices. On the other hand, falling profit margins can hurt a stock, especially if they're caused by a company that's cutting prices to sell its products.On Jan. 13, the stock of KB Home (KBH) crashed 16% after the homebuilder warned that margins were declining. The company said it was being squeezed by rising building costs and falling home prices.There are a variety of definitions for profit margin, but IBD focuses on quarterly after-tax and annual pretax margins.Looking only at quarterly margins can be misleading, as some companies' products or services may be influenced by the seasons.For example, Apple's (AAPL) sales tend to rise around Christmas, while those of homebuilders such as KB Home tend to fall in the winter due to harsh weather.In such cases, it's best to compare quarterly after-tax margins to the same period a year earlier.Also, since profit margins vary widely by industry, it's important to compare companies in the same industry.For example, tech stocks like Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) tend to have much wider margins than grocery stores like Kroger (KR) that have famously thin margins.Just because a stock has fat profit margins doesn't mean it's a buy.Investors should look for accelerating quarterly and annual margins. They should be near or at the company's historical peak and among the highest in its specific industry.A company's annual pretax margin can be found in the Stock Checkup feature at Investors.com and in charts accompanying the IBD 50, the Sector Leaders, IPO Leaders and Income Investor columns.A pair of other measures give an indication of a company's strength.IBD's SMR Rating combines a company's sales, profit margins and return on equity into a single indicator. Stocks are ranked on a scale of A to E, with A being highest. Investors should look for those rated A or B.The stocks in the table accompanying this story were taken from a recent IBD 50 list. All show strong annual pretax margin in the prior fiscal year.

Stock futures pointed to a weak start Monday as the market headed for the last trading day of August and the final week of the summer.
Dow futures traded 105 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures were down 23.7 points and S&P 500 futures showed a 13.3-point loss. All were off early lows.

The stock market today launches with the Nasdaq down 5.9%, the S&P 500 off 5.5% so far in August, tracking toward the worst monthly performance for both indexes since May 2012. But it could have been much worse.
The Nasdaq opens 60% of the way up the month's trading range, after rebounding from a 16% dive. The S&P 500 opens just below the midpoint in its trading range for the month.
The market remains in a correction. Savvy investors can put the pause to good use by building watch lists of stocks with strong fundamentals forming possible bases.
A fairly light week of economic news gets the Federal Reserve's September Beige Book report due out Wednesday, and ramps up to the Labor Department's August payrolls report on Friday.
Today, Kingsbury International reports its Chicago Purchasing Managers Index for August at 9:45 a.m. ET. The Dallas Federal Reserve delivers its regional manufacturing survey at 10:30 a.m.
In stocks, the second quarter earnings season is mostly passed, with only a handful of big names - mostly retailers- expected this week.

New Jersey-based biotech Medicines Co. (MDCO) popped 20% ahead of the open. Early stage trial results presented in London on Sunday showed the shot-administered cholesterol treatment ALN-PCSsc - developed with partner Alnylam Pharmaceuticals (ALNY) - lowered LDL cholesterol levels by an average of 64% for more than 140 days. The results suggest a drug that could manage cholesterol levels through shots two or three times a year. Alnylam rose a fraction before the open.

Leading stocks were under some early pressure, with the bulk of the IBD 50 list steering mostly lower in premarket trade. Losses were mild, however. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) and Alaska Airlines (ALK) slipped furthest, falling less than 1%.

Overseas, China's markets posted a moderately mixed session with Hong Kong's Hang Seng index up 0.3% and the Shanghai Composite down 0.8%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dived 1.3%. Europe's markets were also mixed, with the leading indexes in Paris and Frankfurt down a half percent, and London's FTSE 100 up 0.9% near midday.

The dollar eased vs. the euro and the yen. Bonds edged higher. Oil prices slipped in the 2% range, with West Texas Intermediate trading above $4 a barrel and Brent crude near $49. Call it the gift that keeps on giving. Gift-card facilitator Blackhawk Network Holdings (HAWK) was spun off from Safeway in April 2014, but it hasn't strayed far from its roots in the grocery-store channel. The company still generates most of its revenue from gift cards sold at kiosks in grocery stores and other retail venues. The number of grocery stores,…

WhiteWave Foods (WWAV) has been riding a wave of financial growth and positive analyst comments over the past few months, but as growth is projected to slow further in the first quarter, shares have followed suit. The maker of Horizon Organic Milk, Silk non-dairy milk and Earthbound Farms salads will report Q1 results Friday, and earnings are expected to come…

Kroger (KR) reported third-quarter above Wall Street estimates despite stiffer competition from Amazon (AMZN) and Wal-Mart (WMT).X Estimates: EPS seen falling 2.4% to 40 cents. Revenue up 2.8% to $27.31 billion, according to Zacks Investment Research.Results: EPS climbed 7% to 44 cents as sales rose 4.5% to $27.75 billion. Same-store sales excluding fuel rose 1.1%.Outlook: Kroger sees Q4 same-store sales growth, excluding fuel, to exceed 1.1%."This quarter shows that by investing for the future, our business continues to improve and gain momentum," CEO Rodney McMullen in the earnings release. "We remain confident in our ability to continue to grow identical supermarket store sales and market share for the balance of the year and in 2018."Stock: Jumped 6% to close at 25.86 on the stock market today, vaulting above its 200-day moving average for the first time since late February. Kroger shares rose 3.5% on Wednesday, continuing a two-month rally.IBD'S TAKE: In a discount world, companies like Amazon and Target are looking to private labels to make a bit more money. Last month, Kroger said it is looking at selling its $1.4 billion convenience-store business.The decision comes as Amazon bought Whole Foods back in August, cutting prices on select staples like ground beef, eggs, fish at the at the upscale grocery store.Over Thanksgiving, Amazon Prime members were able to get organic and antibiotic-free Thanksgiving turkey at Whole Foods at a discount to draw more customers to buy its Prime membership.But Kroger had a strong Black Friday."The holidays are always Kroger's time to shine," McMullen said.  "In fact, we had our best ever Black Friday results for general merchandise, led by record sales at Fred Meyer. Everything we are doing revolves around our associates providing friendly service and fresh products to our customers."But not everyone is feeling the squeeze from Amazon. Earlier this month, Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) crushed Q3 same-store sales forecasts and raised full-year guidance above consensus views.Wal-Mart is the largest U.S. grocery seller, and has expanded online ordering and curbside deliveries.Amazon rose 1.3% Thursday, Sprouts Farmers Market climbed 1.3%, and Wal-Mart dipped 0.3%.RELATED: Here's Everything That's Changed At Whole Foods After The Amazon TakeoverRetail & E-Commerce Stocks And Industry News

The major market indexes were modestly higher in morning trade on Thursday, as the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 made fresh record highs, rising 0.5% and 0.4%, respectively. The tech-heavy Nasdaq looked to rebound from Wednesday's plunge that saw many tech leaders hit the deck. The Nasdaq moved up 0.4%.X Among the Dow Jones industrial components, Apple (AAPL) looked to get back on track, moving up 0.8%. Shares briefly dipped back into the 5% buy range from a 160.97 cup-with-handle entry Wednesday before rebounding back out of it.Elsewhere in the Dow, big banks rose for a third straight day, but gains were being trimmed. JPMorgan (JPM) rose 0.4% to set a fresh 52-week high. Shares are now about 10% above a 95.32 flat-base entry after a successful test of the 50-day line.Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs (GS) attempted to recapture its 247.18 saucer-with-handle buy point, but fell just short, rising 1.7%.FANGs were on the mend in early trade in the stock market today, but gains were begrudging as they looked to recover a portion of Wednesday's heavy losses. Facebook (FB) advanced 0.8%, Amazon.com (AMZN) 0.8%, Netflix (NFLX) 0.5% and Alphabet (GOOGL) 0.1%.Amazon.com received dual price-target boosts early Thursday. Deutsche Bank raised its price target from 1,200 to 1,425, while MKM Partners bumped it up from 1,275 to 1,350. Despite Wednesday's fall, shares are still extended from a 1083.41 cup-base entry.Among companies reporting earnings, Workday (WDAY) declined 2% despite handily beating top- and bottom-line estimates late Wednesday. The human capital management software firm fell further below its 110.69 cup-with-handle entry and the 50-day line. The stock triggered the 7%-8% sell signal.In the meantime, Kroger (KR) surged over 11% after the supermarket chain reported better-than-expected Q3 results, shaking off rising competition from Amazon and Wal-Mart Stores (WMT). Still, shares are still well off their 52-weeks high, but back above the 200-day moving average line.After the close, Five Below (FIVE) will report its quarterly results. Analysts expect EPS of 13 cents on revenues of $245 million. Shares were extended from a 54.23 buy point.Within the IBD 50, graphics-chip maker Nvidia (NVDA) rose over 1% to move back above the 50-day line. Shares fell hard Wednesday, down nearly 7%, closing under the 50-day line for the first time since a Sept. 15 breakout above a 174.66 flat-base buy point.On the downside, Alibaba (BABA) was on track to extend a losing streak to four trading sessions, declining 0.6%. Shares were under the 50-day line after giving back an over-8% advance from a 177.10 ascending-base pattern entry.RELATED:Big Events For GM, OPEC, Plus 5 Earnings To Watch: Investing Action PlanDow Jones Industrial Average And Dow Stocks: News And AnalysisFANG Stocks News & Quotes: Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, GoogleThese 7 IBD Stock Indexes Are Beating The Nasdaq Year-To-Date

Stocks stumbled out to a mixed open Friday, as Nike (NKE) pulled down hard on the Dow and data showed durable goods orders rose less than expected in November.XThe Dow Jones Industrial average dipped a fraction, the Nasdaq Composite slipped 0.2% in opening trade. The S&P 500 defended narrow gains, with Kroger (KR) and Capital One (COF) posting its strongest early moves.Bond markets will close early, at 2 p.m. ET today. Stock and bond markets will be closed Monday.Congressional leaders hammered out a stopgap extension agreement to keep the government funded through Jan. 19, avoiding the partial federal shutdown otherwise set to take effect at midnight Friday. The massive tax overhaul passed by Congress on Thursday is on the president's desk, awaiting a final signature.On the Dow, DowDuPont (DWDP) rose 0.8%, while Nike traded down more than 4% as a generally positive fiscal second-quarter report delivered late Thursday was once again tilted by a decline in North American sales. Shares ended Thursday extended, almost 13% past a 57.35 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.IBD 50 name Cintas (CTAS) slipped 2% at the open. A report after Thursday's close showed the Cincinnati-based uniform service's fiscal second-quarter sales and revenue topped analyst targets. The stock ended Thursday near the upper edge of a buy range good through 160.57, after clearing a flat base buy point at 152.93 on Nov. 29.Celgene (CELG) tanked 3%. The company had announced late Thursday that a treatment of Revlimid plus rituximab for a form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma had failed in a phase 3 trial. Celgene shares have been attempting to reclaim support at their 10-week moving average, after a steep four-week sell-off in October.Shake Shack (SHAK) dropped 3% in early action. The burger joint was cut to underperform, from hold, by Jefferies. Shares are extended, up 19% after clearing a 38.80 cup-with-handle buy point Nov. 28.Personal income growth slowed slightly, to 0.3% in November, the Commerce Department said, down from a 0.4% increase in October and forecasts for a 0.4% November gain. Spending surged 0.6%, however, up from October's 0.3% gain and above projections for a 0.5% increase.Durable goods orders also jumped, rising 1.3% in November, though that fell short of the 2% advance projected by economists. Still, it was a big step up from October's 0.4% dip, which itself was originally projected to drop 1.2%.Minus transportation, orders dipped 0.1%, which was below consensus views for a 0.5% gain. Amazon (AMZN) Prime members can now get their organic and antibiotic-free Thanksgiving turkey at Whole Foods for a little bit cheaper than everyone else.XThe massive e-commerce company, which bought Whole Foods in August, is offering a discount on organic and no-antibiotic turkeys for anyone who enters one of the upscale grocer's airy, lushly stocked stores. But Prime members can buy organic turkeys for $2.99 a pound and antibiotic-free ones for $1.99 a pound — that's 50 cents cheaper than the discount for people who aren't Prime members.The discount is the latest attempt by Amazon to draw more customers into its Prime membership program. The move could also help Whole Foods compete for a customer it hasn't always been successful at attracting — that is, the many who don't have $10-$20 to blow on, say, a sampling of Robusto and a bottle of Saison Dupont."This offer is a sneak preview of the special savings and in-store benefits Prime members can expect when Prime becomes the official rewards program of Whole Foods Market," the companies said in a release.Other items will have their prices trimmed starting Wednesday as well. Those items include some boneless skinless chicken breasts, raw peeled shrimp, potatoes, Chobani yogurt, pasture-raised eggs, canned pumpkin and salad mixes.The companies said those price cuts were "in addition to the reduced prices that customers are already enjoying." After Amazon bought Whole Foods, the grocer slashed prices on beef, eggs, bananas, fish and other items.Amazon closed down 0.9% at 1,126.69 in the stock market today. The stock is still within range of a 1,083.41 buy point of a late-stage base. Grocery-store operator Kroger (KR), seen as a potentially big loser in Amazon's foray into groceries, fell 1.9%. Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM), which turned out strong Q3 results despite Whole Foods' earlier price cuts, lost 1.8%. Supervalu (SVU) edged up 0.2%.Big-box chains that also sell groceries like Target (TGT) and Wal-Mart (WMT) dropped 10% and 1.4%, respectively, after Target gave a disappointing earnings outlook and warned of a "highly competitive" holiday quarter.IBD'S TAKE: In a discount world, companies like Amazon and Target are looking to private labels to make a bit more money. Grocery stores over the past year have struggled with lower prices due to a glut of certain types of goods. Consumer preferences have also shifted to the fresher items often found on the perimeter of the store, rather than the prepackaged goods in the center aisles.While Amazon's deep pockets give Whole Foods more room to cut prices, Target and other grocers, whose value game is stronger, have also tried to be a little bit more like Whole Foods.But while Target has tested a few new grocery strategies, the results have been "underwhelming," an Edward Jones research note said Wednesday."We expect the issues within the grocery business will continue to negatively impact results for the next few years because the company lacks a clear, defined strategy to improve the business," it warned.RELATED:Kroger Surges As It Considers Selling Its Convenience StoresThe Huge News Wal-Mart Didn't Make About WagesKroger's Hurricane-Less Outlook Adds To Amazon, Wal-Mart Fears

Organic foods distributor Hain Celestial (HAIN) has helped stimulate the popularity of healthier foods, a trend analysts expect to continue when it reports second-quarter results Wednesday.Analysts see Q2 earnings per share rising 18% to 52 cents and sales growing 33% to $715.51 million. The company, whose brands include Terra chips, Celestial Seasonings tea and Rice Dream milk substitutes, has turned out EPS and sales gains ranging from the high teens to the upper 30s over the past two years.Hain shares rose 2.4% to 54.05 in the stock market today after testing a recent low Monday morning.On Aug. 20, shares gapped up and finished 11% higher after reporting fourth-quarter results that topped views. After losing and retaking the 50-day line for much of the year, the Q4 report jolted the stock above the line for the next two months. The 50-day line is often a key test of investor support.Shares bounced off the line in October, and rose on Nov. 6 after the company's Q1 EPS topped views and sales missed slightly. The company during that quarter voluntarily recalled Arrowhead Mills nut butters on fears they might have contained salmonella. The stock fell below the line last month. Still, the stock is up 17% since the beginning of 2014.The company has grown through acquisitions as well as online and international sales. As reported here, Hain's U.S. market chief John Carroll said over the summer that Amazon (AMZN) was one of the company's biggest accounts. During the Q1 earnings call in November, CEO Irwin Simon said acquisitions grew revenue by $131 million during the quarter and cited continued strength in the U.K.Amazon shares rose 2.8% Monday.Hain's results come amid a more upbeat analyst sales outlook for natural foods, which are likely to be found in such upscale grocers as Whole Foods (WFM), Sprouts (SFM) and Fresh Market (TFM). Cowen, Sterne Agee and Bank of America analysts in recent weeks have cited consumers' increasing willingness to pay more for presumably healthier, higher-quality products, potentially rewarding those stores and the companies selling there.Still, RBC Capital Markets in December downgraded Hain to sector perform, saying organic sales had slowed domestically. And Zacks noted that the natural foods space has become more crowded, potentially weighing on Hain's Q2 resultsWhole Foods shares closed up 2%, while Sprouts and Fresh Market shares both fell about 0.5%.Hain's products aren't exclusive to higher-end stores and wealthier consumers. They also appear in Chipotle (CMG) restaurants as well as Kroger (KR) and Costco (COST) stores, a reflection of growing health awareness.Kroger shares were up 0.9% while Costco climbed 2.1%.WhiteWave Foods (WWAV), which competes with Hain, reports fourth-quarter and full-year 2014 results on Feb. 12. It shares closed 3% higher.

Kroger continued to dominate its industry in the third quarter, topping analysts on strong grocery and fuel sales while gaining market share — and driving its stock up to an all-time high Thursday.
The largest U.S. supermarket chain's earnings per share minus one-time items climbed 30% to 69 cents on an 11% hike in revenue to $24.99 billion.
Wall Street was looking for 61 cents per-share profit on $24.83 billion in revenue.
Kroger netted $362 million, up 20% from $301 million a year ago.
It was the fourth quarter in a row that Kroger's (KR) earnings topped Wall Street expectations.
It was also the third quarter in a row that included earnings and sales from its Harris Teeter acquisition in January.

"We are well on our way to achieving our 10th consecutive year of lowering costs and reinvesting those savings in our people, products, pricing and improved store experience," CEO Rodney McMullen told analysts .

Kroger, which employs about 375,000 worldwide and operates its namesake stores plus Ralphs, Dillons, Food 4 Less and other brands, raised its full-year EPS estimate to about $3.34 from $3.25, topping projections of $3.29.
Those figures imply Q4 EPS of 86 cents, roughly in line with consensus estimates for 87 cents.
The company expects 4% to 5% same-store sales growth in Q4.
Kroger has boosted sales of natural and organic foods as Americans move to healthier diets. It competes there with Whole Foods Market (WFM) and Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM).
Focusing On Faster Growth

"Kroger's growth is driven by increased focus on faster-growing categories like natural foods and generally healthier food products," S&P Capital IQ analyst Joseph Agnese said. He put a buy rating on Kroger with a 12-month price target of 68.

BB&T Capital Markets analyst Andrew Wolf, who also has a buy rating, said that Kroger's growth was driven by an improving economy that puts more cash in consumers' pockets and by lower gas-pump prices, which he called "a de facto tax break."
"They got a lot of earnings growth in their core food merchandising," Wolf said. "And the wholesale cost of fuel is coming down quickly, so they had a windfall on the fuel side."
Factoring In Fuel Prices
Kroger's long-term net EPS growth rate guidance is 8% to 11% per year. But if fuel margins return to lower levels, Kroger expects 2015 results to be closer to the low end of that range.
S&P Capital IQ's Agnese thinks its guidance could be stronger.

"They were conservative because they see gas margins returning to historical levels. But that's hard to predict and may not happen. Kroger continues to outperform not only in foods but in staples and their pharmacy business."
Kroger generated $3.38 billion in gasoline sales in Q3, about 15% of total supermarket sales.

Kroger shares traded up 3.6% Thursday to a fresh closing high of 60.78. Did consumers chow down on health foods during the winter months?
Investors will get a chance to find out when Whole Foods Market (WFM), Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) and Hain Celestial Group (HAIN) report quarterly results in coming days.
If analysts polled by Thomson Reuters are right, the results will be a mixed bag.

The analysts expect natural and organic foods supermarket operator Whole Foods to see a nice pickup in sales and earnings growth when it reports second-quarter results on Wednesday after the close. They estimate that earnings will rise 13% from a year earlier to 43 cents a share, following a 10% gain in the prior quarter.
The analysts forecast that revenue will jump 11.5% to $3.705 billion. The jump would follow a 10% increase in the prior quarter.

Healthy foods grocery store operator Sprouts is expected to see a sharp slowdown in earnings growth from the prior year's robust pace when it reports first-quarter results on Thursday after the close. Analysts see earnings rising 13% from a year earlier to 26 cents a share. That's a healthy rate but slower than the 71% jump that the company saw in the prior quarter. Still, the rise would mark the ninth straight quarter of at least double-digit earnings growth since the company went public in August 2013.
Revenue is seen growing 19.4% to $862.5 million, slightly less than the 21% it turned out in the prior quarter.

Organic and natural products company Hain Celestial has logged double-digit earnings growth in all but one of the past 15 quarters. Analysts see it breaking that streak when it reports third-quarter results on Wednesday before the open. They see earnings rising only 2% to 45 cents a share, after reporting a 26% gain the prior quarter.
The analysts forecast revenue to rise 17.38% to $654.27 million. That would be a slower pace then the 30% gain that it saw in the prior quarter.
Sprouts and Whole Foods are a part of IBD's Retail-Super/Mini Markets industry group. Whole Foods has a Composite Rating of 84 out of a possible 99. Sprouts has a Composite Rating of 79.
The group also includes giant supermarket operator Kroger (KR), which has a high Composite Rating of 93.

Hain Celestial is a part of the Food-Packaged industry group.
